text: From a 12 oz bottle into a pint glass. Pours a very cool purpleish color. Little lacing or head. Fantastic fruit aroma! Cherries, berries and grape soda... but in a good way. Mouthfeel is moderate to thick, but in a lager type way. Taste is also straight dark fruit with some minor whiskey or bourbonish flavors. Fantastic. Definitely let this one warm up a bit, it makes it 5X better than if its fridge temp. Great stuff!
Grower poured into a snifter. Opaque medium with no head. Aroma is clove, medium body, a little carbonation, and little lacing. Taste is clove, bread, chocolate, and some caramel.
full flavored caramel and chocolate mail, a great balance of tastes and ABV which is well hidden, my favorite of all ... great on a cold night and just as good on a warm summer night....love it
Dont recall when or where I had this. I enjoyed the beer and want it again. Had on tap

tap . Pours dark , clear brown . No real head . Smell is a bit sweet . Taste is bitter chocolate, malty , yeasty a bit as well . Taste is intense, malty and sweet in the back . Way more intense ( way better ) than I expected .

Old review from 2008. 
12 oz bottle poured into a pint glass
Pours very dark brown light barley penetrates but does show a slightly reddish hue. Head is light tan which falls to a ring.
I get dark bread, wheat, toasted malt, fruit and some molasses.
Sweet and fruity in flavor. I get prunes as well as the molasses malt with a little bit of spicy hops on the finish
Medium body and quite smooth with a little carbonation tingle.
This is a very nice wiesenbock - great for a cold weather drink. Has similarities to a dopplebock in its richness and fruitiness. Interesting take and delicious. Its hard to believe that its 9.5%!

Bottle sample at a tasting at the Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks DSG. Hazy dark brown and headless. Picklish aroma, a little nasty with hints of wheat beer characters underneath. Very sour, olive water taste. No carbonation, full-bodied, picklish finish. Nasty.
Bottle sample at a tasting at the Beer & Beyond shop. Thanks DSG. Pours brown hazy with a brown head, aroma of honey, coffee, caramel and yeast, flavor of pickles, roasted malt, medium bodied.

Bottle shared at a tasting at the Beer & Beyond shop. Dark brown to black with a tan head. Aroma is sourish, fruity, with olives and some roast. Sourish flavor, somewhat roasty, with fruits and light spiciness. Medium-bodied. Seems unintentionally infected, but quite pleasant this way.

Bottle:
Dark, cloudy brown with a small, tan head
Smoked wheat, dark fruit, chocolate aroma.
Taste is sweet, chocolate malt, banana, caramel.
Slightly boozy-sweet.
Thick and rich.
Great Beer!

Bottle (huge thanks to jtclockwork). Banana, orange, clove, caramel malt and astringent alcohol aroma. Dark brown with small tan but long lasting head. Sweet banana, chocolate-caramel malt, clove and mildly bitter astringent alcohol flavor. Absolutely delicious.
Draft at craft ale house. Pours dark brown or nearly black. The aroma has a very fruity smell with a bit of roast. The taste is medium roasty, sweet, more sweet, almost caramel and cherry.

Tap at gingerman as I try to get drunk quick, what is this 2002? Any ways pour deep brown with nose of odd fruit and cola. Tastes of cola, banana, blackberry, white wine, light chocolate. Drying finish. Thanks NJ

Draft. Cola cited with medium tan head. No lacing. Aroma of apple and roasted wheat. Taste mostly follows suit with some dark fruit notes on the finish. Medium mouthfeel with sufficient carb. Slight boozy finish. Good.
Pours a lovely black with tan head. Has a very chocolate malt smell. Goes down very smooth with a clean after taste.

Bouteille achetée au Half Time (Poughkeepsie). Robe couleur jus de raisin, surmontée dun épais collet beige. Arôme de blé et de pomme. Acidité vineuse, manque déquilibre. Assèche complètement le palais. Pas vraiment mon style.

Dense mocha head over opaque body with ruby highlights. Aroma of dark caramels, burns taffy, plums/raisins/dark fruit. Taste of some wood and sour character, roast developing on tongue, sour fruit, nuts, full body. Palate tangy and lighter than expected, but with a warm boozie feeling down the throat.
Pours dark brown, with small head. Smells of wheat, yeast, banana and spice. Tastes the same  with a mild alcohol aftertaste.

12 Fl. Oz. Bottle. Pours a dark brown with minimal off white head that disappeared very quickly and no lacing on glass at all. Aroma of fruits, spices, wheat and caramel/molasses. Taste is also quite sweet but spicy balanced with toasted malts. Very good overall.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2013 
Location: Draft at Texas Arizona, 1/3/13


Aroma: The nose has a lot going on, wheat, clove/winter spices, banana, and raisin to name a few

Appearance: Pours a dark amber-brown color with a soapy beige head and medium lace

Flavor: It is medium sweet, much like the nose, fairly complex, with lots of spice/clove flavors

Palate: It has a medium-plus body, a tingly feel, and average-plus carbonation

Overall Impression: 
This one was served way too cold, and really needed to warm up to develop, but thats not the beers fault.  Anyway, I thought this was quite solid, with a nice amount of complexity.  Good stuff.

Served on Nitro-Tap at Als of Hampden into a tulip glass.

A - Pours deep, dark, brown with a small thin cap of off white head leaving little to no lacing down the glass.

S - Smells of dulled wheat, chocolate, banana, light spice, sweet toffee, and some dark fruits. Not as strong as I was expecting but still plenty going on. The booze is ever present, getting stronger as the beer comes to room temp.

T - Flavors are similar to the nose with plenty of chocolate, clove, dark fruits, tart cherries, and bready wheat. The booze is light at the beginning only getting stronger as it warms. Finish is a mix of chewy wheat and lingering sweetness. Good balance overall, just a touch too much booze.

M - Medium-Heavy body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Full, chewy, feel with plenty of dry lingering chewy sweetness. The booze is ever present.

O - Not so much. I thought this one was ok but not anything mind blowing. The combo of strong flavors and 11% ABV. really make this one hard to drink.

12 oz bottle / 2007. vintage?  Shared at Aarons big German beer tasting. Poured a deep cola brown with a thin tan head. Nice nutty aroma with caramel and malty notes. Still decently carbed with banana bread and caramel flavors. Finishes with  a bit of vanilla and a semi-sweet warming finish. Not bad for its age.

Bottle @ Dans, courtesy of doodler. Huge mother fucking thanks!!! Reddish brown appearance with a small tan head. Super rich caramel, dark fruity, banana, cinnamon, toasty malty aroma. Tangy, rich caramel, toffee, tart, banana, spicy, very caramel malty flavor. Cool beer, thanks Scott!.
Aroma of floral, wheat and subtle banana.  Pours deep brown.  Taste of caramel banana and wheat.  Very pleasant.

Draft. Dark brown/black color. Thin head. Smells of carmel, maples and wheat. Taste is more malty then wheaty. Booze is not present. Very drinkable. It almost has a mocha and sour taste to it. Very interesting

Appearance - Surprised by the deep black color. Short lived, light brown/amber head
Aroma - Light roasty notes with a bit of funk. Delicious full body aroma
Taste - Notes of chocolate and light roasted malt. Little to no hop character (or aroma). 
Palate - Smooth, crisp full bodied mouth feel 
Overall - Solid beer overall. Only being sold at the brewery this year and I got this bottle from a friend (Thanks Steve!) who attended the release party. Nothing mind blowing but absolutely worth a try if you come across this beer. Although a "winter wheat" this beer would be perfectly fitting for a crisp Autumn day and would pair great with roasted squash/pumpkin!

Pours a brown cola medium clarity, very thin head and minimal lacing. 
Nose- cloves, molasses, figs and other dark fruits. Taste- tart, almost lactic like qualities initially with a high roast like quality. Difficult to pick up a significant wheat component. A very unique take on the style, esp with the level of sourness. Carbonation is moderate, drinkability on the low side- this is a thick chewy brew.

12oz bottle, 2008 vintage thanks to Arbitrator.  Pours cola brown in color with a small, quickly fading tan head.  The aroma is somewhat stout-like with caramel, molasses, milk chocolate, toast, and a hint of wheat.  The flavor has slight sweetness and a substantial tartness as well (not infection though).  Chocolatey, wheaty, and toasty, with caramel malt.  Medium-bodied with a low level of carbonation.  Good beer overall, if a little past prime.

Bottle. Pours a dark, brown-ruby with a faint, brown head. Aroma of cocoa, dark and ripe fruits, and hefty malts. Flavor is fairly sweet with caramel and toffee, chocolate, grape and cherry. There are also some mild, winter spices and booze. Light to medium in body with smooth carbonation. Finishes sweet, lightly bitter and a little thin. Not bad.

Bottle acquired via trade with gothood...thanks Bobby!!!  Surprised by the dark Coca-Cola pour that produced a 1/2 inch eggshell head.  Aroma is dark fruit, caramel, and citrus, along with a little roasted malt.  Flavor is lemon funk, honey, brown sugar, raisin, and bitter chocolate.  This one definitely seems soured.  Medium mouthfeel.  Interesting.

Bottle courtesy of jtclockwork gives dark cola-colored fairly clear beer with thick beige persistent head.  Aroma malts, molasses, a whiff of alcohol.  Taste initially dark fruits ,then malts and wheat with a hint of citrus.  A touch of sourness - it says best to drink by May and it is June 3rd so I would think it should still be OK.  Not as much sweetness as others have noticed.  Finish a bit sour.  Alcohol well disguised.
Nice dark pour. Nose and taste is bourbon, deep malts, molasses, brown sugars, barley and grains. Rated 11/15/2000

A- Body is an opaque cola color and pours with an approximately 1/2 finger off-white head that quickly fades to a thin collar. No lacing is left behind in the glass.

S- Cocoa and dark chocolate come through. Some alcohol esters behind and a strong aroma of sourdough bread.

T- Initial flavor is mostly of tart sourdough bread with a hint of fruits such as plum and prune. A hint of clove comes through for the finish as the tartness intensifies. Interestingly enough what lingers on the palate is a hint of what seems to be cocoa and sweet raisins.

P- Mild to moderate carbonation and medium weight body that is neither smooth or crass.

O- This is certainly and interesting beer that has been on my wants list for awhile now...and I am glad I have had the opportunity to finally try it! Definitely worth a try and I will have it again-if the opportunity arises.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-13-2010 21:39:01

Appearance: Served up an almost black body crowned with a tall, proud, lasting tan head.

Smell: Lightly roasty, chocolate-based aroma with notes of dark wheat malt, dark caramel, cracked cloves, and well-ripened dark fruits.

Taste: Mildly, modestly sweet taste of chocolate-coated roasted grains further brushed with a bit of caramel. Slight flourish of tangy malted wheat. Hint of spicy clove character and smoked mingled into the dark fruitiness reminiscent of prunes and black cherries. Very subtle bitterness. Picks up a bit more sweetness as you go. A final touch of roast and dried fruits in the smooth, warming finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium-high carbonation.

Drinkability: Good stuff! Presents a good mix of flavors with a well-rounded smoothness. It certainly went down with ease for purportedly being 9.5% ABV.

12oz Bottle, purchased at Half Time - Poughkeepsie, NY. Pours a rugged dark teak, with a half-finger of almond-flesh-colored  head. Aroma speaks of umami, reduced hazlenut sauce, and soy. Dense and browned. Flavor is similar with a strong sugary side to things. This is damn near barbeque sauce. A puckery blend of raw apple cider, blackstrap molasses, black cherry juice, sassafras, mission fig pudding, and burnt caramel. Its got a decent flavor profile, but the melanoidins and glutamates are almost too concentrated and biting for me. it really resembles soy sauce in some way and starts to near Sam Adams Triple Bock. Dense, dark, and malt. Toeing the line of too much.

Got a 6 pack about 3 years ago.  Sadly this isnt holding up as well as I wished or as a dopplebock should.  Deep brown color, hint of brown at the edges.  Head dissipates very quickly to nothing.  Aroma is rich toffee, spicy and toasty.   Palate is flat.  Flavor is not overwhelming, actually fairly light as compared to other DBs.  Caramel sweet with a hint of alcohol.  Hops add slight green, dry finish.  I think if the carbonation had held up, this would have been much better.

2009 Bottle - Thanks Beerloco!!! - Pours a transparent dk amber with a tiny ring of beige for a head...aroma is fruity and spicy, toffee, banana and grain...flavour is similar, cola, caramel, pear and banana, light clove and wheat...chalky yeast and cocoa on the finish, cant wait to try the eisbock!!

A: The pour is dark brown in color with some reddish highlights and a fluffy tan head.

S: The nose is fairly typical for a weizenbock. An interesting mix of bananas, cloves, sweet caramel, dark fruits and yeast.

T: The dark fruit and caramel translate quite intensely to the flavor. The beer is very sweet without as much in the way of the spicy, yeasty, and banana character that you expect from a Bavarian wheat beer.

M: The carbonation is moderate and gives the beer a fairly full and creamy feel on the tongue.

D: This was an interesting take on a weizenbock. I am more of a fan of the German examples (who isnt?) but that was certainly passable.

Smell of bananas, bananas, bananas leap out of the glass along with vanilla, mild wood and a slight booziness.  Flavor is dark toffee like the brittle of peanut brittle and a sweet bitter sensation towards the end that melds with a light carbonation to make a spicy sensation.  A bit candyish but I think that may be the point.  Light to medium body with a Fullers porter mouthfeel.  Really nice beer here and very glad I finally found some.  Thank You High Point Brewing.  2010 12oz.

Bottle.  Pours a deep dark brown with touches of purple and garnet and a medium sized taupe head.  Sweet malt and banana, subtle hints of cocoa and toffee, light esters.  Bananas and chocolate, rich caramel.  Medium bodied.  Tastes a touch like coco-puffs on the finish.  Slight dark fruit and warming alcohol on the finish. Rather tasty.
Draft @ RnH. Brown pour with no head. Dark fruits, caramel and sweet malt aroma. Flavor follows aroma and has moderate chocolate malt body.  Best brew from ramstein yet.

Very disappointing beer...weak cocoa aroma, very light mouthfeel (at least it hides its high ABV well), and the flavors it brags about having--clove, apple, blackcurrant--are so subtle as to be virtually nonexistent. Overall tastes more like a standard English ale than a Weizen of any sort....i love NJ, but this is the fourth out of five Garden State microbrews that, to use our dialect, totally suck.

RnH: Maybe I had a bad batch, or better beers before tasting this one... honestly think its overrated.  None of the fruits and spices described were available in the aroma, I actually found it to be very flat, some roasted malts at the most.  The taste was a bit better, however not much more than a dark yet weak weizen...
DecemBeer. Sample from a bottle shared by decaturstevo.  Dark black, tan cover.  Caramel aroma, alcohol, fruity.  Taste is caramel, cocoa, fizzy body, alcohol.
Dark brown pour with fluffy head and lace. Aroma of coffee and a hint of chocolate. A metallic flavor, fruity as well, and a decent warmth. Too fizzy for me, but pretty good.

Bottle at an impromptu tasting at lithys. Pours dark brown, almost black, with a lovely tan head. The aroma is caramel, oak, grass, and some plastic. The flavor is chocolate, spicy wheat, bubblegum, cigarettes. Decent, but weird.

Draft. Pours dark brown with a beige head. The aroma is fruity and spicy, with some lighter yeasty notes. The first thing I wrote down after flavor was "weizen-bocky". Seeing that it is in fact a weizen bock, that doesnt really help much. Fruity banana esters, sweet malty notes, solid spicy yeasty notes throughout. Very good.
Got this on tap at the brewery at a beer sampling. Dark almost black with a tan head. Deep flavors ranging from apples, banana, clove, to chocolate and caramel. Good winter beer.
31st May 2008. Dark bock - almost black. Mildlt toasted malt. Banana and other fruits that defy description. Smooth and a bit different.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy pale orange with a busy white head.  Heavy wheat in the nose mixed with yeast, lemon, and pineapple.  Flavor is dominated by wheat, lemon, bread, and honey.  Starts and finishes tart and dry.  Refreshing, goes down smooth for the ABV, alcohol is barely noticable.  Very good.
dark brown with no foam, really awful sour aroma and flavor of soured catfish bait, I was really looking forward to this but will have to try again

some guy i sorta know used to be a brewer at the company and we always chatted about beer. he gave me a bottle he had in his car and i tried it was oh so very impressed. best of there line in my opinion. spicy and bitter yet refreshing and perplexing. left me wanting more, so i got some more... and more. all in all, sorta yeasty, a tad spicy like almost cinnamon, with a strong, bitter but not alcohol overwhelming aftertaste.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours just about black with a massive brown head that overran the glass and made a f*cking mess all over my counter.  Pleasant aroma of malt, malted milk balls and chocolate.  The flavor is less malty and not as sweet as the aroma.  In addition, there is a very slight metallic twang to the finish.  Not a horrid beer, but not something Id be likely to try again either.

deep brown/black pour with a beige head that quickly disappears.  Aroma of... surprise... wheat.  There is a funky undertone of vinegar or something acidic.  Flavor of wheaties with lots of sugar.  Not too bad for a wheat beer but I dont expect to be trying it again soon.
black pour with a dark tan head.  Aroma of pickled chocolate and wheat.  Flavor follows through,  I think I held on to this one too long as it definitely seems a bit...pickled.

Dark dark brown brew with a quickly dissapearing light brown head. Mild aroma on nuts, banana, clove and light cocoa powder. Medium, slick bodied with a big banana flavour acompanied by some cocoa, apples, clove and a restraint sour berry touch. Very drinkable but not too exiting.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown body with a coca cola head.   Sweet and malty nose accents of dark fruits cherries and tannic apples.  Caramel and cotton candy.  Very freshly apple up front with a moderate caramel and coco body.  Finish is bready, sweet with hints of caramel and spice.  Good brew.

12oz bottle thanks to Johnykat.  Pours black with an overzealous, light brown head.  Nose is lemon yeast, spice and banana.    Taste is of banana, bread and chocolate.  Mouthfeel is medium with lots of carbonation.  Pretty good.
Draft. Poured dark w/very little head.  wheat, rummy etc.  Pretty darned good, dangerously drinkable.

On draft at Capones.  Poured deep brown with next to no head.  Lightly undercarbonated.  Sweet, chocolatey, spicy, meh.  Not sure I get this style...completely different from other Weizen Bocks Ive tried, and not in a good way.

Aroma is very spicy, mostly cloves, wheat, some banana, raisins.  Dark brown/black, completely opaque.  Decent sized tan head.  Very dark for this style.  The flavor is wheat bread, cloves, fruit.  Medium mouthfeel.  The finish has a mild hoppiness, and an alcohol burn.  Not bad, not as good as I had thought it would be.

Pours very deep bronze with a large fizzy tan head that turns to nothing IMMEDIATELY.  The aroma has very dark wheat with a good amount of spice, some banana and cream.  Medium / thin body with some short lasting carbonation.  The taste has some lightly charred toffee, rich wheat and phenolic spice.  The finish has a lemony citrus twang.  An okay beer.

Bottle in trade from JB185.  Thanks!  Pours a dark maroon brown color with a quickly dissipating fizzy beige head.  Seems lighly carbonated.  Smell is sweet and malty with dark caramel and some clove yeastiness.  Taste is a bit tart, slightly chocolatey and a very prickly, foamy mouthfeel that detracted the ability to note the flavor.  Definitely an overcarbonated bottle and not sure if the slight tartness is intended either.  Would probably have liked it better if not for the carbonation/infection issue.

thanks to Johnnykat for this. Dark brown pour.  Way over carbonated.  Brown head and spotty lace.  Head takes an extremely long time to settle.   Soft nutty aroma with subtle malty overtones.  Slightly better then alot of the recent reviews I have been reading.   Rich nutty flavor with a caramel metallic finish.  Alcohol warming late on the finish

Bottle.

Pours dark without a small head. Strong, malty aroma is really quite lovely, rich and full but the flavor disappoints: all soy sauce and green apple. The alcohol is too apparent and I simply have little-to-no interest in making any headway into this one.

Bottle shared with some of the Carolina crew... I think from Ethan.  This bottle was a year old, and either the aging did not treat the beer well and/or it was infected.  The pour was deep brow with a foamy tan head.  The nose and taste offered up chocolate, molasses, soy, and some very metallic notes.  Tingly mouthfeel.  Not very good.

Thanks Jabic. Bottle from last year. Pours a murky dark brown with a 2-3 finger creamy tan head. The nose smells rusty, some soy characteristics, sort of like a dubbel. The flavor is the same, a lot more soy though. Not so sure a year did this one well.

12 ounce bottle in weizen glass.  Dark dark brown with lasting light brown head and lace.  Roasted chocolate covered fruit and clove aroma.   Rich roasted malt and fruity raisiny tangy middle with mild spiciness and roasty slightly nutty fruity finish.  Medium-full body and medium low carbo.  Excellent soft mouthfeel.  Very well hidden alcohol.  Complex and delicious.  A little wierd, though.  Not refined and fruity life Aventinus.  More like a robust tangy wheat porter.  Nice.

After reviewing this beer and looking over the previous reviews I wonder if I got the bottom of the barrel on this one.  Seemingly I may need to revisit this one some day.

Smell: A sweet wheat malt aroma was all I was able to pick up.

Appearance: Poured dark a brown with a hint of red.  Light brown head that quickly dissipated and provided no lacing.

Taste: Sweet alcohol taste upfront that gave way to a sour finish.

Mouthfeel: Thin with no carbonation.

Drinkability: Became almost tedious without any carbonation.  Again this was on-tap so I may have had the dregs.

Bottle from eclectic. Thanks! Aroma is pretty sweet with lots of dark fruit, a touch of yeast, chocolate. Pours dark brown with a thin non lasting head. The flavor is robust and fruity. Lots of dark malts create a fruity sweetness that pervades. Some chocolate and light roast too. Smooth with very light carbonation and some alcohol warmth.

Bottle courtesy of JB175. My first from the Garden State  thanks Jason!  Pours a murky reddish brown with an initial 3 finger fizzy tan head that fades fairly quick and zero lacing.  I didnt expect this one to be dark at all. Nose is sweet malt, dark fruits and light roasted coffee.  Taste is dark fruits, bitter dark chocolate and sour coffee grounds.    Theres definitely an alcohol burn in the finish as well.  Medium, semi-creamy and  prickly mouth feel.  Not bad  not what I expected at all, but a decent brew.

bottle:  pours a very dark dark brown good small tan head. aroma is a good roast slight chocolate very little wheat. and some dark fruits linger. flavour is  roasty and slight chcolate and a better wheat profile then in the aroma good carbonation and great finish.

Pours opaque mahogany with crimson edging. Barely a trace of spritzy head rose up before instantly dissapearing. Zero lacework or retention.

Aromatics are full-on malty, with a trace of chocolate and a good whiff of alcohol. Quite clean and caramel-stuffed.

On the thick side of medium bodied, sticky and slick. Low carbonation adds some cloyness.

Rich malt, caramel, and chocolate lead off the pallet. Alcohol follows through with some substantial warmth. A slight tang from the wheat but otherwise a very clean lager.

Finishes with lingering caramel, chocolate and some faint wet paper.

This one is tasting a bit stale, or maybe it was never too spectacular to begin with?
The lack of carbonation and poor retention is not a good sign, regardless.

Pours a dark cola with a strong head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is very complex. Black pepper, cloves, allspice and some sweet malt. Taste is disappointing. I taste some smoke, a horse blanket aroma of dust and some sweet malt but very little in the way of wheat.  Perhaps it was the bottle. It wasnt one of my favorites. Ill try again and re-rate in the near future.

This poured opaque and mahogony to black in color with a thick head that dissipated quickly.  The nose showed off wheat, dark fruit, banana and some expresso.  In the mouth the beer is light to medium-bodied with fresh acidity.  This actually comes off quite fresh which is unexpected based on the nose.

2005 Bottle. 

Pours out a very dark brown with dark red around the edges when held to light. Head was fairly big and a light tan color, retains well, but not as pillowy as one might expect. The smell is one that I’ve been waiting to experience, almost a revelation. It smells like a wonderful Christmas cookie. It’s like a chocolate dipped banana plum, mixed with caramel and molasses cookies. Taste begins with some plum and a bit of dark fruit, plenty of Christmas spices as well, then ends up having a hint of burnt caramel and just a touch of coffee-like roastiness. Carbonation is on the higher side with just a little bit less than medium body. Alcohol is very well hidden in this one. I’m going to see if I can’t get more of this so I can enjoy plenty of it during the next holiday season, although I’m sure this is great in any weather.

12oz bottle. Pours dark brown with a very small, brown head, no ret, no lace. Smells dark and malty, slight alcohol. Tastes big and dark sweet malty, not overpowering though, very nice. Not what I was expecting from a wheat beer, but good and flavorful. Full body, good carbonation.

12 fl. oz. bottle via sammy (thanks!), served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass.
App.:  Moderate cola, vanishing tan head, clear.
  
Aroma:  Lots of boozy currants, raisins, light coffee, milk chocolate, vanilla, minty herbals, some other dried fruits, a bit of wood and some light warm spices, some brown sugar and molasses.

Palate:  Medium+ body, fairly soft but present effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Some of the currants, clove and esters, a bit of wood and chocolate, a bit of molasses; quite tart...thats not right, is it?; a bit of mineral and coffee to finish.

Surely this is infected.  Would like to try a fresh bottle, because the nose is very promising.

No trip to NJ is complete without a Ramstein brew. Dark almost cola-like appearance, very minimal head. Aroma is very spicy, with the cloves very evident. Taste was sweet but not too overpowering. Palate was very smooth. Overall this is a very drinkable beer and I was very impressed.

Pours extremely dark, inky purple to virtually black in color.  A fizzy tan head disappears rapidly and leaves absolutely no lacing behind.  Dark, fruity aromas of fig, raison, and plum dominate the nose, with sugar glazed banana bread and cinnamon adding further richness.  Flavors again show alot of dark fruit, though things turn a bit more sour and tannic, almost vinous on certain spots of the tongue.  The back-and-forth play between sweet and sour is interesting, with sweet, dark fruits and caramel dominating the foreground, only to be overtaken and surpassed by sour grape and fermented figs in the aft.  Medium-plus bodied and lively carbonated, this brew finishes on the dry side.  Overall, a decent example of the style, but I tend to dig a fuller, bolder, less sour Weizen Bock.
4/07 tasting. Aroma of brown sugar, banana nutbread, and spice. Flavor is banana nutbread, spice, and nutty. Nice mouthfeel.

Bottle (12oz) shared with HogTownHarry & tupalev -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours a very dark brown with an average size diminishing tan head. Aroma of toasted malt, coffee, chocolate, dark fruit, yeast, some sweetness and more -- very nice! Flavours sweet and roasty along with dark fruit, spices and chocolate. Bitter coffee finish. Creamy/oily mouthfeel. Alcohols pretty well hidden. Very well done and another awesome beer tonight!

Definitely one of the better wheat beers Ive had. Probably the darkest wheat Ive ever poured, nice dark opaque mahogany brown. Wispy head. Think of a typical wheat with cloves and banana but with additional dark fruit such as prunes. Palate is perfect - nice and fully bodied, not watered down like a lot of wheat brews youve probably had. Overall a very good wheat brew with a very good punch. Be careful with this one! its easy to drink but has a high ABV.

Bottle shared with Hogtown Harry and Blankboy, Harrys bottle.  Dark fruit, hops on interesting aroma.  Very dark brown, thin off white head.  Interesting taste - lots of dark fruit (my theme for the evening), grapes, hops.  Oily mouthfeel.  Complex.  Alcohol hidden.  Good again!

Bottle (12oz).  Shared with blankboy and tupalev, my bottle via trade with markgugs.   Near-murky deep ruby-purple, small foamy off-white head.  Dry dark roast caramel malt, heavy sweet spice/yeast, floral, slightly musty.  Taste follows, solid dark fruit malt backbone, dry leafy and very dry, near brazil nutshell bitterness in the finish.  Solid chewy dry body, nicely aged, that 9.5% is really well hidden - fantastic beer - complex.

(Bottle, BB May 08)  Pours a dark brown (near black) body with a small fizzy tan head that quickly dissipates.  Aroma of anise, rye, raisins, brown sugar, clove, and toastiness.  Flavor of sweet plum, rye, black currant, caramel, and raisins.

Another bottle shared by Crosling.  Poured a hazy amber-brown color with a thin beige head.  Aroma of wheat, light spice, and a hint of fruit.  Smooth light wheat entry with undertones of caramel and fruit (apple), with a hint of yeast and alcohol on the finish.  As it warmed up it became much smoother and the alcohol became less noticeable.  Smooth, lingering caramel finish with light apple undertones.  Really became better as it warmed.  Thanks Nick.

Bottle from The_Epeeist on 2/22/08.  Pours with large head of large bubbles that dissipates quickly. Deep dark brown color.  Some sour off flavor.  Not very drinkable.  I hate it when this happens, and I dislike a beer much more than others.  This often happens with dry roasty beers.  Theres no roast in this beer.  Perhaps a little dry.  Some DMS.  Im not sure.
12oz that Ive had for a while, bonuses by someone or many people.  Pours dark brown with a thin tan head.  Nose is a nice malted wheat.  Taste is sweet, malty, and a bit tart.  Pretty tasty brew.

unfortunate that i could not get the flavors as described but no doubt most folks would clearly tell that this is quite good beer. sweet and satisfying with well hidden alcohol this beer is a find. raisin like in the taste and sticky sweet (as in the good kind) you would be sorry to pass this up whatever youre beer style favorite is. well carbonated for the style i was surprised at how very well this beer is comprised.

This beer is one step below pitch black. Held to light, it shows a little bit of ruby. Nose is like a sweetened molasses. It almost smells like a syrup. Flavor is rich and thick with extremely strong malty characters. Mild molasses in a deep way. Robust, full, and lasting. Never even hints at dropping off. Feel is very thick on the liquid. Low bubble. Extremely drinkable. Well made and oh so robust. If you can get your hands on it, go for it.

The best of the bunch from Ramstein.  A perfect blend, not too much of that German malted wheat nose, not hot at all for a beer this size, a beautiful near black color with no dark-roasted malt flavors.

Bottle.  Dark brown with a foamy beige head.  Aroma of tart berries (cassis?) with a mild baking spice note, dark bready malt and some brown sugar/molasses.  Tangy malt flavors with an underripe berry tartness.  Underlying sweetness of the malts are cut at the very end with a hoppy/spicy dryness.  Lively carbonation.  Alcohol hidden. Very good.

Bottle.  Dark ruby in color, with an offwhite head.  The aroma is of spice and bitter fruit.  The texture is full with just enough body to feel creamy.  You can detect the wheat maltiness with almost a berry like finish.  Very sweet as it warms up, transitioning from a crisp hoppy character to a sweet, alcoholic, smooth flavor.  Very good.
Pours black, tan head.  One smell and you know that it is a wheat beer!  Smooth flavor with a nice follow though.  Must be the New Jersey water!

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2008 12 oz bottle purchased at the Oak. Pours a deep dark brownish/black with a thin coating of carboantion on my glass and an initial huge light tan frothy head that quickly and totally dispates. Aroma of chocolate, vinous notes and slight wheat in the back ground. Thin watery mouthfeel with slight stingy carbonation that dances around on the back of my throat. Flavor starts off with lots of vinegar and vinous qualities but moves onto a slight bitersweet chocolate that turns into total chocolate on the aftertaste. This beer has the best aftertaste that I have ever had and hides the alcohol very nicely. Interresting beer that is definitely worth trying.

Warm, glowing pour of blackened burgundy with a glow of electric red underneath.  Aroma of banana, clove, almond oil; some spicy funk of sun dried tomato and dry paprika with a slippery sweetness of caramel toward the end.  Salty, fruity, zesty.  Bursting with sharp clove flavor and given to  heavy bubblegum sweetness with hints of seared purple onions, balsamic reduction, and powdery pepper.  Carbonation seems a bit reckless and impossible to restrain; medium bodied and irreparably sharp in the mouth.  Faint chocolate and hazelnut precede another whisk of brisk spice in the finish   .  The elements are definitely in place, but the final impression is lacking in some indescribeable way.  Wheat may just present a bit too strongly, enough so to suffocate the depth of malt that this style needs to properly balance it.  Thanks Andrew!

Draught:  Aroma of fruit, roasting, spices, and a hint of smoke.  Poured black in color with a small, creamy, tan head that diminished but lasted.  Opaque.  No lacing.  Medium sweet flavor.  Flavor of spices, cloves, nutmeg, bubblegum, malts, and chocolate.  Light to medium body.  Thin, chalky texture.  Soft carbonation.  Sweet, spiced finish.

12-oz. Thanks, Kim! Black with clear orange and toffee highlights. Headless, laceless. Huge toffee and caramel nose. Medium body, light carb. Light sour wheat on the mid-palate. Roast and chocolate notes appear as well. Cookieish finish.

NorCal December 07 tasting - In many ways, this beer reminded me of Aventinus, which is a good thing. Maybe not quite as complex and rich as it, but still an outstanding beer just the same. A big aroma of chocolate, cherries, molasses, sweet malts and bready yeasts (sort of reminds me of a scented candle you might light for Christmas). Appearance is dark brown in color with an off-white head. Flavor is quite excellent with the noted cherries, chocolate, cloves, and allspice. Supple carbonation makes this beer outstanding.
I was very impressed with this beer.  Deep rich flavor, almost had a texture to it.  Very nice mouthfeel and very very nice hidden alcohol content.

The first of the darker wheat beers Ive tried.  Nice rich dark brown/near black color with just a hint of bubbly foamy head.  Hints of clove and and chocolate in the flavor.  A quality winter offering, and definitely recommended.

12oz bottle from MrBendo - thanks! My bottle says best by August but not which year - oops! Im at least 3 months overdue, possibly more. And the brew certainly seems to have become a bit muddled (though Ive no idea what it generally tastes like). The aroma is fairly spicy, like one would expect from a weizen bock (I was immediately reminded of Aventinus). But strangely, the quality of the taste/palate was altogether different. The mouthfeel was smooth and creamy, the flavors mostly chocolatey (!), and I was reminded of an over-the-hill milk stout. Ill have to try another bottle.

Date: 07/08/2006
Mode: Bottle
Source: Trade

black with ruby edges, thin fine brown head, sweet chocolate and spicy wheat aroma with light roasted, big creamy body, rich chocolate flavor offset by the spicy character, nice sweetness, light bitterness in the finish, hint of alcohol shows up at the very end

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 14/20
Rating: 3.6/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **4

Thanks MikeTD. Dark dark brown pour, with 0 head. Aroma is sweet malts and bourbon. Flavor is chocolate, coffee, and caramel. Flat and really lacking profile probably because it was old but not sure how old. Thin and watery, just not right. More caramel sweetness but just a flat chocolate and roasted malt taste. I need this fresh.

Bottle via JB175.  Dark color.  Smell of black licorice, pepper, prunes, smoke, malt, rasins, coco, cloves, ginger and light alcohol.  Taste of prunes, rasins, pepper, clove, malt, chocolate, smoke, caramel, nuts and alcohol.  This one is good.  Very enjoyalbe.

12oz bottle from TURDFERGUSON.  Aroma:  Lots of caramel and breadiness.  Raisins, berries, and grapes.  Light clove and banana.  Some chocolate and vanilla as it warms.  Appearance:  Dark reddish brown in color and hazy.  Light beige head was full and foamy with good retention.  Fair lacing.  Flavor:  Bready malt and caramel upfront transitions to a mouth full of fruit(grapes, cherries, raisins, berries, banana) and spicy cloves.  Chocolate hits right before the finish.  Palate:  Full bodied and creamy.  Moderate carbonation.  Nice alcohol warmth over entire mouth.  Overall:  Wow.  This was great.  Really hit the style right on.  Wish I had more.

Thanks to Dickinsonbeer for that one.  Dark brown body with a very small beige head that turns to no head at all.  Tough one to describe. All kinds of flavours in there.  I got yeasty notes of banana and bubblegum next to dried fruits, a distinct Dr Pepper flavour, tobacco, black chocolate, distant berries (including blueberries!?) and a light roastiness.  Thats a lot of individual flavour elements but the beer doesnt feel all-over-the-place.  Many different spices too with black pepper being the dominant one.  Peppery hops finish.  Carbonation is too soft and thats too bad.  The body feels full yet kind of watery but thats probably because of the lacking carbonation.  Plus your 18 year old nephew will find you so cool when you tell him that Ramstein kicks ass.

Bottle from Capones, recomended by Stegosaurus. Beautiful suprisingly dark brown almost black pour (THIS IS A WHEAT BEER). Chocolate, spice and raison/wheat aromas. Flavor captures your palate and leaves you quite satisfied. Absolutely amazing.

Bottle from JB175; Thanks; Nose of black berries, caramel, banana, and cocoa; clear, dark cherry brown with a medium tan head that laces the glass; flavor of caramel malt, dark plummy fruit, some brown sugar sweetness, and a light chocolate note in the medium body. The finish is sweet  and fruity with a miniscule amount of alcohol warmth. Very good Weizen Bock!

Bottle from Dickinsonbeer.  Thanks Paul.  Pours very dark brown with a small off white head.  Aroma is malts, dark fruits, and cocoa.  Flavor is sweet malts, a little spice, dark fruits, and no alcohol to speak of.  Medium mouthfeel, goes down smooth.

Bottle courtesy of Sammy: Poured a cloudy dirty brown color beer with a small foamy head with limited retention and no lacing. Aroma of sweet malt with some very subtle dry fruits. Taste of sweet malt is domination with again some very subtle dry fruits and some light alcohol notes. Body is full with some limited filtration and some low carbonation. Not exactly sure what to make of this beer and wouldnt mind having another shot to rate this beer.

Bottle sampled from Capones. Pours dark with a decent size beige head. Aroma of bananas, spices, chocolate, and dark fruit. the flavor is sweet, caramel, chocolate, bananas, spices, dark fruit. Very nice!

Bottle.   Pours dark brown with a tan colored head that disappears quickly.   Aroma is dried cherries, banana, chocolate, rosted nuts.   Flavor is dark sweet dried cherries, banana, toffee, chocolate, caramel, and toasted nuts.   Palate is medium bodied, mild carbonation, finishes on the sweet side, smooth texture, alcohol is well hidden.   Really enjoyable brew.   One of the best weizen bocks Ive ever had.

12 oz bottle thanks to dickinsonbeer.  Pours a ruby brwon with a thin white head.  Nose of red fruits, plum, banana and chocolate.  Very fruity ripe fruits, plums, wheat, toast, a little sour and a hint of bakers chocolate.  Medium bodied and flavorful.  I wasnt expecting much out of this stuff, but im impressed.  Nice fruity, sour, toasted, cocoa, balance.  Good stuff, thanks paul.

12oz, pours dark with small tan head around the rim. nose has plums, nuts, wheat, and banana. flavor of dark fruits, wheat, toasted nuts, sweet caramel. abv well hidden. mouthfeel is a tad water. carb. low. tasty stuff.

Thanks to mrbendo for trading this one to me. Pours almost black with a small quickly fading head. Nice full aroma of malts, ripened fruits and mild cocoa. Flavor is very smooth. Raw sourish malts, hints of fermented fruits such as bananna. Also faint mild spices. This is a wheat beer you can really sink your teeth into. Thanks again Todd.

Rated at the Pewaukee Tasting II 5/5/07.
Appearance  Cloudy brown, little head, 
Aroma  Bold sour wheat nose
Flavor  Sour, yeasty, 
Palate  Medium, a touch of astringency at the end

Average head with little lacing.  Strong dark malt and wheat character.  Aroma of chocolate and bananas with a hint of clove.  Rich and full on the palate with a bit more chocolate and a little tartness.  A subtle smokiness on the finish.  Decent and good representation of the style.

Pours a very dark bordering on black color with almost no head.  Flat like appearance.  Aroma of malts, currents, black cherries, plums and chocolate.  Taste is slightly carbonated with hints of currents, black cherries, chocolate, malts and plums.  A slight smokey finish.

Very dark brown in colour, thin beige head, light lacing.  The aroma is quite malty, lots of toffee sweetness, light alcohol, some roast, light chocolate.  The flavour is rich, slightly chewy, lots of toffee, chocolate, some smoke, roasty.  Smooth mouthfeel, medium body, medium carbonation.  Finishes long, smooth with some chocolate.  Excellent winter warmer, very good.
355ml bottle obtained in a trade with <a
href=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?U target=blank>joeec5, thanks Joe.
No best before date.

Bottle from trade. Pours a  medium bodied dark brown color with a this  light tan head. Aroma of roastedwheat, caramel  and bananas. Taste is sweet with a flavor of over ripe fruit and roasted malt. Very satisfying with a smooth finish.

The beer pours to a dark cola colored body with a nonexistent head.  The aroma has a strong toasted wheat and is reminiscent of one of the Bells wheat series beers.  The flavor is wheaty with light notes of soy and bananas.  Dark yeast strains.  The palate is average with some tartness and a moderate drying to it.
Pours a dark brown with some brown head, but not too much.  Chocolate cover frozen banana.  The aroma and flavor are full of it.  Really nice milk mouthfeel.  Damn fine beer.

Bottle, at csbosox KC tasting 4/14.  This one was the biggest surprise of the night, really, really nice.  Aroma is sweet cane sugar.  Pour is muddy brown, with almost no head.  Taste is malt and wheat, in that order.  Sweetness some through in this as well.  Really great balance and drink ability to this one.

Bottle shared by bgburdman. Dark brown pour with a short white head. Aroma of booze, caramel malt, a bit of wheat and mint. Flavor was of caramel malt laced with mint and some yeast. Malty mouthfeel medium body with a earthy finish.

Very Dark Brown with Light Tan Head.  Sweet Malt, Fruit...Notably Currant on the Nose. Nice Thick and Creamy Mouthfeel.  Caramel and Chocolate Notes Mix with Black Currant.....Light Wheaty Aftertaste. Well Balanced for a Higher Alc Brew.  Overall Just Very Well Done. A Winter Warmer but Still Very Approachable. I Wish This Was Distributed to MN!

Bottle from hophead. Poured a dark brown with almost no head at all. In the aroma I swear I smelled olives, figs, and some wheaty notes. Flavor was sweet and had a dark maltiness and notes of dark fruits. Pretty unique beer.

Matt at Capones suggested this one for me. Poured from a 12oz into my pint glass. pours dark yellow brown, almost no head. Slight lacing. Primary scent is bananas and... soy sauce? The banana scent stays true throughout the initial taste, but the soysauce that i smelled comes through as a burnt butter-cream taste in the middle and the end. The mouthfeel starts out smooth and ends refreshingly crisp. Alcohol content is apparent in the aftertaste, but there is almost no warming except at the very bottom of the throat. I rarely have this style of beer so it is a unique treat for me. Low carbonation with a nice combination of fruit and cream.

12oz bottle, no date notched  from Dickinsonbeer, thanks Paul!  I can almost see through this beer, but not quite.  It is a deep brownish ruby with only a couple beige bubbles for a head.  Aroma of toast, bananas, and a bit of New Belgiums house yeast.  Flavor has some roasted and toasted malts up front, banana, light tartness, and an earthy burnt finish.  Burps burnt plastic, though this doesnt make me hate the beer like it does with a lot of the other plastic beers.  I would not believe this was 9.5% if someone told me.Full bodied with a little bit of carbonation.  Not a bad weizen
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: UPDATED: MAY 26, 2007 Draft at Capones. Cloudy brown, nearly opaque. Aroma of wheat, cherry, banana and chocolate. Very complex flavors; dark fruit, tangy, dark malts. Medium to full body. No sign of the alcohol. Wonderful.

A very good beer.  Color is brown with amber edges.  There are so many flavors in this beer and they work so well with each other:  tastes of carmel, apple, malt, roast, little banana, and sweet fruit which is balanced by a smoky, but subtle finish.  I really had no idea what to expect when I bought this beer, but it was well worth it.  I think if this beer had more name recognition or wider distribution it would be rated higher.  I would recommend giving this beer a try.

Smokey, roasted, fruity, chocolatey taste with a deep burgandy-brownish-black coloring.  Slight head and nicely done natural carbonation.  Doesnt taste much like a wheat beer, however it is very similar to Aventinus.  Ill give the nod to Ramstein for overall flavor and drinkability.  Alcohol is very well hidden within the malty taste.  Since the hops are pretty well buried, theres no real aftertaste to speak of........which makes it easy to drink another!  An excellent brew.

12oz bottle, courtesy of markgugs.  Thanks, Mark!  Needed something for a hot afternoon outside.  Pours a dark, cloudy brown appearance; significant, light-tan head with great structure and retention - until it slowly disappears to almost nothing.  Lots of chewy banana bread and cloves in the aroma; hints of spiced nuts.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: malt-driven, chewy nougat and caramel character upfront, lots of bread and clove and yeast; hints of a citrus hoppiness underneath all that.  Medium finish, showing milk chocolate and a chalky dryness.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2008 bottle-cheers pops- pours a deep brown to black- no head really little sign of carbonation, smells quite odd, woody, fruit that at first i thought smelt like my roomates dog, but upon closer inspection is much nicer. lots of sweet malts brown sugar and figs. tastes smoked wood, and a subtle fruit overtone, berries, stinging sweet finish.

thanks zeswaft.  pours real dark with no head.  roasty aroma with lots of sweet dark fruit.  taste is exactly the same.  super sweet and quite roasty.  i could see myself not liking this much in another setting, but i like it for the moment.  definitely estery, but i dont really get the wheat character so much.  cool.
Pouris brownish black with no head...smell is nice and toasty with some nice light fruity notes...taste is sweet with lots of dark fruits...seemed imbalanced...

Bottle shared by bgburdman: Brown in color with a small white head. Aroma, minty, some dried fruits, roasted malts, and some yeast. Flavor, cloves, wheat, some light fruits, yeasty, and some minty notes. Nice medium body, some earthy hops on the finish, pretty good stuff.

Cold 12oz bottle:  Pours a dark brown color with a thin tan head.  Aroma is of rich malts, dark fruits and subtle earthy hops. Taste is of rich malts, caramel, chocolate dark fruits and subtle earthy hops.  Light to medium bodied, low carbonation and smooth.  Ending is of rich malts, subtle earthy hops and some alcohol burn.  (*Thank You, Andrew!*)

Dark brown pour with minimal tan head.  Aroma of roasty malt, brown sugar, some nuts, slight rauchiness.  Tastes roasty malty, with some molasses, nut, and brown sugar.  Medium palate with a nice complexity and great balance.

12 oz bottle courtesy Lou18. Very dark brown colour with a mostly lasting creamy beige head. Ive had stouts that werent this dark. Big banana, light chocolate, roasty, and alcohol aroma, with some acidic coffee and possibly lemon notes. Banana, chocolate, roasty, and coffee flavours. Full bodied, rich, smooth, with a refreshing drinkability that belies its abv.

Very dark brown, amber/brown edges, 3cm creamy tan head. Nose of toasty grainy wheat, spicy yeast, cloves. Flavor adds roasted cocoa, light ash, and subtle dark fruits. Medium body is just more carbonated than balanced. Very well done winter brew.
Very strong yeast aroma with some vinuous notes.  Black with a huge tan head.  The palate is very full.  Yeast and plenty of malt flavors. Roasted and full taste--very interesting.

A: Im probably too much of a n00b to discern the difference, but this Weizenbock looks near-identical to all quality stouts Ive had. Which is to say, solidly black, with very little dark cream head and minimal lacing, if at all. Appealing at the very least.

S: At first you wonder where the aroma of this beer is at all, but a couple of good solid deep inhales reveal a tasteful, sweet scent beneath the obvious dessert flavors. The more I smell it, the better it gets, like a fresh piece of pie. Its fantastic.

T: Im not sure I can even review this beer unbiasedly (is that a word?), because its absolutely one of my favorites. Its uncharacteristically smooth for such a big beer, lots of bready, malted flavors. Every mouthful of this beer rewards with big flavors of mild milk chocolate, banana cream pie (I swear!), malted sugars and more. Its amazing.

M: So chewy, and so delicious, like a piece of white bread that has been sitting in a sugary chocolate concoction for the past 2 weeks. I almost want to freeze this and eat it with a spoon.

D: I only knocked this down a peg because its 9.50% ABV and it kicks my tail all over the room. Too bad because I often want to drink about 12 of them in a sitting. VERY drinkable, dangerously so.

HIGHLY recommended, a favorite beer of mine.
Aroma is very bitter with some hints of alcohol.Pours dark brown with a tan head.Roasted malt and spices stand out in the flavors.Mouthfeel is thin with some roasted malt in the finish.

On tap at Barcade: Deep brown pour with blood red hue in the light. Sweet malty aroma with hints of dried fruits (figgy, banana) The flavor is malty as well with sweet brownsugar notes and some figs. A bit metallic with a light roastyness in the finish. Kind of simple, but solid.

12 oz bottle- Pours a dark cola like brown with a small tan bubbly head. Scents of chocolate malts,hints of bananas and a bit smokey. Scent is better than the flavor, but still very good. Much of the same flavors with a clovey finish.

Pours out black with a small brownish head. Aroma of some fruit and roasted malt. Taste is complex and very smooth. Notes of roasted malt, dark fruit, caramel and slight alcohol and yeast on the finish. Very solid beer with an extremely well masked alcohol content.
From growler. Black with minimal head. The aroma was of clove, banana, roasted malt, yeast, and nuts. The taste was the same with a faint sour taste. Smooth and full bodied. very good beer.

12oz btl, courtesy of The_Epeeist, another from Matta. Gorgeous, silent pour. A silken beige head sits atop a black body with chestnut and ruby hues. The aroma initially reminds of New Glarus Black Wheat. Heavy wheat notes, pervasive roasted malts, cereal graininess, no hops noted. Also scents of caramel, dates, figs, ripe banana. Flavor is buttery smooth black wheat, with clove, more banana, yeast and an interesting bell pepper addition. Slightly soured finish, probably due to the age of the bottle, though that isnt indicated anywhere on the packaging, tisk tisk. Fantastic retention, I can rouse up a good head with a light swirl. Palate is very grainy but smooth. A little vegetal. I would love to try this in weather that is less than eighty degrees, stupid Florida. Pretty good brew. After trying it twice I enjoy it quite a bit, but can think of plenty of similar beers that I liked more.

On tap at Capones.  Pours a hazy dark brown with an average creamy tan head that left lacing.  Aroma of toasted/roasted malts, banana, clove, some dark fruits, some citrus and wheat.  Flavors along the same lines...some nuts, lots of banana and clove and a great roasty/toasted malts.  Very well done Weizen Bock...probably the best I have had!

Tap at Hop Devil Grill.  Very dark black beer with a thick off-white head.  Aroma is dark and toasty.  Chocolate and wheat in abundance, but the yeast seems to be on the clean side.  Plum and prune along with dark toastiness.  A bit of spiciness on the back, along with a fair shot of alcohol.  Seems a bit stale and less than it could be.

Bottle courtesy of Mista Styles!  Poured a clear, deep plum with a whole bunch of rising carbonation and a minutes worth of thick tan head.  Aroma was huge and tough to get a grasp of... oaky lactic sourness, black currants, bakers chocolate, and drawn caramel arose from my glass after much contemplation.  The flavor found banana and wheat sourness, toasty bakers chocolate, black currants, dates, and smoky oak bitterness... accented by spicy yeast and a splash of rum.  Heavily-bodied and creamy across the middle of the palate, fizzling out a bit toward the edges.  This left a long finish with rum-soaked oak and tangy wheat tartness.  Quite a substantial brew!  Thanks Chris!

Dark brown with some haze.  Pours up a big tan head that collapses leaving freckles of lace.  Caramel wheat and orange banana.  Salty licorice bubblegum and cloves with a smooth, substantial body.  Light carb buzz.  Clean finish, a bit metallic.  The name is quite appropriate.

Poured a dark brown color with red edges small head.  Aroma was of yeast wheat and cloves and some other spices in there.  Flavor was much the same.  Very well balanced with just the right amount of alcohol hotness in there.  Good Good beer.

Bottle from my secret santa. Aroma has a lot of sweet teriyaki, husky wheat, salt, white wine vinegar, sweet cherries. Very interesting and different and enticing. Flavor doesnt have quite the same profile, though also seems to mix the typical dry wheat with fruits and strange sweetness: apple, blackberry, salt, raspberry. Very good.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2007 This is one terrific beer. Solid black color and a big frothy off-white head.  Aroma is smoky and chocolaty.  Flavor is sweet, burnt toast, and a little smoke.  Excellent balance and very smooth texture--perfect amount of carbonation.  9.5% abv?  You gotta be kidding. This beer is the total package. Simply Delicious.

pours dark with a dark brown almost purple head. aroma of plums currants cream and soem spice. it really smells amazing. nice full rounded toasted malt bitterness flavor smoothed out with a luscious fruityness. i wouldnt call this beer hoppy or malty just very well balanced. i will say that the smell is so amazing the flavor really had no chance to match it. but still i could drink this everyday. and no trace of alcohol.
dark beer banana mos def malty nutty goodness very full tasting dark good winter beer I wish i didnt drive 70 miles just for a 12 dollar six pack tho but its peace

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2007 Deep, almost black color with medium head.  Aroma has some banana, dark fruits, chocolate, and a good deal of wheat and dark malt.  Taste is sweet dark, roasted malts with chocolate and sweet wheat tastes.  Overall, pretty good winter sipper.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2006 Re rate: 12 oz  bottle purchased at the brewery.  Appearance, roughly the same- very dark brown with a small tan head.  Aroma:  rich caramel, chocolate, with alot of  fruit overtones, banana, dark raisins, plums, etc.  Also a touch of ethanol in the aroma.  Taste is big and complex, chocolate, caramel, dark fruits abound, light amount of spices and a good dose of alcohol warm in the finish.   Original rating 7-4-7-4-15.  First rating came from 2, 8 oz servings at Andys on draught 11.29.06
GBof A PA-12 oz bottle-pours a light brown head and black color.  Aroma is dark malt-sweet, dark fruit.  Taste is dark malt-sweet, dark fruit, secondary hops.  OK carbonation.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2007 12 oz bottle via Dickinsonbeer(thanks!).... Pours a ruby black with almost no head. Nose has lots of fruity easters and alocohol. Taste is a combination of sweet and sour. Cherries, lemons, strawberries, pears, wheat, a little chocolate malt and a strong alcohol finish. Thin body. Pretty good but just a bit much alcohol in the finish...
3/31/07 rerate*******orig was 8/4/7/3/14....wow this has aged nicely in a year.....it is now one of the best beers i have tasted with some nice smokey and chocolate notes coming out from under the wheat. The heat is almost gone. This is sublime....

12 oz bottle, via Styles.  Pours a mostly clear very dark brown colored body under a very fizzy medium brown head that completely vanished.  Aroma is quite earthy and grainy with lots of wheat, a touch of alcohol, and some fruity esters.  Flavor is as earthy and raw as the aroma suggested.  All wheat and a touch of chocolate, bananas, light coffee, and some alcohol.  Mouthfeel is full bodied with an efforvescent fizzy carbonation level.  Overall, I had a hard time trying to really describe this beer.  I know its good, and that I liked it, just not so sure how to elaborate better.

Bottle.  Espresso colored with a tan head.  Nose is super malty, buttery, toffee, caramel, vanilla, prunes, alcohol notes.  Sweet and creamy tasting with a slightly smoky, acidic, and bitter finish.  Chocolatey and nicely balanced.  Dry finish.  Well balanced, a very nice beer, love the malts.

Dark brown, almost black with a small head. Aroma is a bit of smoke and some dark fruit. Oh....this is tasty. Wasnt sure what to expect, but I like it. For a bock, I love it. Burnt malt all over the place.

Bottle.  Dark brown, hazy pour...minimal tannish head.  Big sweet malty aroma...clovey, bananas too.  Flavor is equally malt, toffee-ish, dark fruits...smooth.  Full bodied..very little bitterness.  Nice light chocolate edge...mild bitterness in the end.  Great bock.

Thanks to Zathrus13 for sending me this bottle. Pours a dark murky brown color, nice sized light brown head that fizzes up and sits back down quite loudly. The aroma reminds me of chocolate covered bananas fried up. A little hint of spice in there as well. The flavor again reminds me of a chocolate covered banana split. Tasty and easy to drink, this is a fine brew.

12oz bottle via trade with beastiefan2k - Thanks Eugene! - Pours dark brown almost black with a creamy tan head.  I was surprised at the appearance.  Was thinking this would be like Bells winter wheat.   Aroma of cloves, light bannana, a touch of chocolate, and some black currant.  Flavor contains all of those.  Clove, chocolate, bannana, black currant, and a touch of caramel.  Full body and quite heavy for a wheat beer yet quite creamy on the palate.  Alcohol cannot be detected throughout.  The black currant flavor throughout this is fantastic.  It is what sets this apart from other weizenbocks that Ive tried.  Im very impressed with this brew and I enjoyed it start to finish.

Bottle.
Dark brown coloured with a fast disappearing beige head.
Aroma of spices, alcohol and dried fruits.
Sweet flavour of malts, caramel, dried fruits and spices.
Bottle. Almost black colour with a small beige head. Dry fruits, spicy aroma and a sweet light alcoholic, dry fruits, spicy taste. Medium body with a light roasted, dry finish. Strange but not bad.
Reddish, brown colour with a tan head. Malty aroma with dark fruit sweetness and a light spicy touch. Malty flavor with a solid caramel sweetness. Coffee bitter notes in a dry finish.

(Bottle (best before 8/06) via trade with <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=1 target=blank>jimmack, thanks Jim!) This pours a dark birch-beer brown color with a big foamy tan head. Aroma is bananas and some wheat malt. Palate is kind of prickly, fairly soft, lightly syrupy. Taste has a mild molasses quality, along with some brown sugar, with banana and vanilla in the finish. Interesting stuff, my first really dark wheat.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Pours black and almost opaque with a creamy, beige head. This by far is the darkest wheat beer Ive ever sampled, and markedly darker than any German Dunkelweizen. Very roasted, almost coffeeish aroma. Medium-bodied with great, roasted coffee notes and an edge of chocolate. Sweetish and very lovely - but I really cannot pick up any traces of wheat in here. Thanks to Degarth for sharing this. 030406

Perfumey alcohol, spices, malt and mild fruit notes in the aroma. Dark Brown to black with a creamy light tan head. Roasted malt, spices (nutmeg and/or clove) with a burnt and grainy flavor and feel. The alcohol is utterly unoticeable in the flavor though you can smell it. Departs a good bit from most Weizenbocks, but touches some of the bases and tastes decent enough.
Tap.  Bubblegummy oily flavor.  Blubbergum.  Flouride gel fruit.  Medicinal.  Slightly unpleasant.  Dark.  I think I now officially eschew weizen bock.

Bottle courtesy of Hopistotle420.  Poured a very dark, completely opaque brown into my beautiful Aventinus glass.  No head, but i do suck at pouring.  Aroma is fruit and chocolately--def some currants in there, apples maybe, bananas i guess. Flavor is very malty with chocolate smoke and a little alcohol. Am very surprised to learn that this 9.5%abv.  Very thick (almost like a sweet stout), and well balanced overall.
Very good, but Ill stick with its german cousin when given the choice.

Bottles courtesy of Styles and tpkenned - thanks guys!  Deep, opaque and muddy black in color with a creamy tan moss head that hovers on the surface throughout.  Nutmeg, brown sugar rolls, cloves, prunes and cinnamon protrude for the nose, accentuated by chocolate powder over frozen bananas and earth sodden leaves after a cleansing rain.  Flavor attenuation brings on spritsy dynamics.  Curt, forward footed cocoa prunes.  Dirty copper pennies and gritty dark cigar wrappers, curling around the tongue and scratching the roof of the mouth.  Dry, black pepper serves to spice.  Letting it breath for about 45 minutes improved it dramatically.  The effervescence backed off a bit and helped it seem more balanced, all the while as a chocolate banana bubblegum flavor manifested.  The outset is laden with prunes pulled from burnt brown sugar, unrefined toasted cocoa and an overall heavy, full fledge finish.

Bottle courtesy of Lou18. Almost black dark brown body with a nice fluffy tan head that fades fast. Yeasty aroma reminds me of Aventinus at first but not quite the same. Imagined banana and fruit, light notes of toasty malt. (6+) Flavour is a touch discordant, with sweet malt wrestling with dry fruity tones for dominance. Slight yeasty estery undercurrent. Finishes drier than expected. Medium palate (3+) Very nice beer but lacks the coherence and oomph to escalate to the next level.
Freshly opened case-Strong wheat and over-ripe banana aroma -flavor is sweet and thick with smoke and brown banana with a slightly vinous backround.  Really good and made in NJ

Thanks to some gracious Northern RateBeer trader for sending this brew my way. 

2004 bottling
Pours a mysterious stormy night black body with some crimson edges.  The head, a dark hue of tan, stands fine bubbled and tall. The aroma is a fruitcake of pit fruits and sweet breads, sweet breads as in the compound of grains, not the cooked innards of a wild animal. The flavor brings out beautiful contributions of raisins, coco, dates, fig, wild red cherries, toffee, vanilla, almond extracts This beer is amazingly complex and worthy of reflection!  This beer reminds me of a local desert Ive had a few times, Cognac Flambéd Banana Truffle the charred chocolaty crust overtop the sweet caramelized banana, surrounded by the sweet oaky bourbon like suggestions of Cognac. 
The palate is a marvelous silky texture as it coats the thong and throat moderate effervescence.. a very luxurious beverage!

2004 bottle.  Pours a cloudy brown with a tannish head.  Smells of raisins, bananas, apples, berries and chocolate.  Taste is sweet and fruity with a nice balance of bitter and sweet.  Full bodied mouthfeel and finish.

Pours black with purple hues.  Big off white head that doesnt quit.  Leaves nice little rings around your glass with each sip.  Smells of bitter apple.  Tastes of malt and alcohol.  A little thin through the taste.  Finisihes with a slight malt feel.  First of this style, has potential.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2006 Pours deep and dark.  Carbonation is slight, but I am not in this for the bubbles.  Aromas of ripe cherries and chocolate.  A bit on the sweet side, but helps hide the 9.5% (not sure how this can be so strong).  Smooth as glass, not hot at all and this is a fresh batch.  I have tried 2 year old WW and its outstanding, this one is well on its way as well.  Finishes with hints of dark fruit and wheat malts.  Outstanding.

Maple and toffee, with hints of coffee cream, burnt popcorn, clove-like yeast, chocolate, vanilla and fruit platter in the nose.  Opaque brown color.  initially sweet on the palate, like grape jelly.  Burnt cocoa butter, black currant and plum follow, with light hints of chocolate wheat in the backround.  Fluffy as hell.  Gotta say I like this brewery and their concept.

Thin, dense dark brown head.  Reduces slowly.  Rich wheat aroma with green hop pelets and bananas.  Kind of a sickly smell to it also?  Light carbonation.  Color is a very dark port brown.  Dark roasty flavor.  Wheat is not very apparent but a little clove and dry dusty bitterness.  Mostly roasted grains.  Slick mouthfeel and a bit of bitterness at the finish.  Brew actually tastes a little flat.  Decent but could be better.  Hides its alcohol very well though.

As I pours this dark brew a fresh aroma of banana bread wafts to my nose.  The beer is topped by a frothy, one-finger thick, brown colored head that sits atop a dark, purplish-brown colored beer that might be more aptly described as black.  The aroma is fresh, with a nice wheat tartness, definite notes of clove, and a sweet plum like fruitiness.  As the beer warms it begins to pick up a soft note reminiscent of chocolate and a hint of roasted coffee beans.

The taste has a definite sweetness up front, but it is soft and reminds me of a just ripe plum.  As this beer moves to the finish it picks up tart wheat notes and a nice hint of coffee and roast grain.  The roasted note is what really lingers here, like a slightly astringent, burnt barley husk.  There is some spicy clove notes here as well as a hint of banana like notes.  This beer really has a nice fruit character to it; along with the sweet plum notes I also get notes of raisins, and notes reminiscent of fresh figs.  I really like how this seems to be light on the palate, yet still has a mouthcoating richness to it.  It is definitely not a light beer, but there is something about the creamy smoothness of this beer which gives it that sort of feel.

This beer is definitely quite nice, it strikes a good balance between rich flavors of fruit, spice and roast and still being quite quaffable.  The only drawback here is a slight, burnt grain astringency in the finish, and this is fairly subtle.

Holy Sh!#, I just looked at the alcohol content.  One thing I have got to say for this beer, I would never have guessed it was anywhere near 9% alcohol; it really hides it quite well.

Thanks Jeremy for giving me this bottle. Even though it might be bad, Ill give it a try. Pours a dark, dark color with a disipating tan colored head. Sweet malt, toffee, and a fruity aroma. Kind of heavy with a sticky aftertaste. But, some caramel notes. Some sour apple as well.  Definitely tastes like it was on the shelf for a while, but has the sense that this was a great beer. Hops is all gone so that kind of sads me. Anyway, I wish I had this beer when it was in its prime. My rating is based off what I imagine this beer being, not what it is after improper aging.

Pours dark brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma had caramel, toffee, chocolate, coffee and courant.  Taste was mainly dominated by caramel and toffee with some chocolate and cloves mixed in as well.  Palate is excellent with a port mouthfeel.  Apple comes into the aftertaste.  Very good Weizenbock.

Pours a deep dark amber/brown with mahagony highlights and a nice lasting head.  Aroma is oxidized bananas, ripe apple, wheat, chocolate and caramel malts.  Flavor is moderately sweet with more banana, fruity esters, and a very sweet caramel malt backbone.  Very smooth aftertaste.  I almost want to say that this is better than Shcneider.  Ill have to compare side by side to find out.
UPDATED: JAN 8, 2007 Pours dark brown, with a tan head.  Aromas are bananas, cloves, and fruit. Flavors are cloves, spice, bananas, fruit, and yeast.

Thanks to Dickinsonbeer for bringing this to the Yeha.  Poured dark brown with an off-white head.  Aroma of caramel and bubble gum.  Taste is apples, pears, bubble gum, mildly sweet with a dry finish.

Toasty roasty malts and alcohol, but of fruit and clove.  Full-bodied rich and warming.  Esteriness (hefe-yeast character) is light to medium.  That is often distracting to me in weizenbocks, as a dark alcoholic clove bomb is unappealing.  Rich thick and warming.  This is quite nice.  Thanks a ton to Duane for working hard to hook me up with this.
Dark brown color with a cocoa-colored head.  Aroma is fruity, sweet, and some caramel.  Tastes of apples, caramel and malts.  This is a great beer.

Bottle:   Aroma of apple, banana, chocolate, and caramel.  Pours a dark brown with only the slightest hints of orange when held to the light.  Insignificant off-white head.  Lots of apple up front.  Light caramel and chocolate in the finish.  Moderate wheatiness throughout.  Hints of banana in the finish.

Tap.  Delicious.  Not overly dark and the flavor allows the wheat beer notes to come through.  No discernable coffee flavors which is a real turn off for me.  Not a dark beer lover, but this was very enjoyable !

expresso with amber highlights when held to a light.Tan head that vanishes to a ring that edges the beer .Aroma is chocolate covered cherries.Taste is smooth semi sweet dark maltiness.
medium body low carbonation makes for 
a pleasent drinking expierence.
Thanks Lou 18 for the trade!

What an incredible story about this beer: For some reason that I cant even remember now, I placed this beer on my want list nearly 2 years ago. During that time I neither saw  or heard of the beer again thereafter. So imagine my suprise when my great friend Jeremy (jgb9348) found this beer for me, and even more amazing, got it for FREE. He was on a roadtrip in New England and found this at a store. The keeper said the beer had been there forever and that he wouldnt feel right charging Jer for it. So opening the bottle I had no idea what to expect. It pours the darkest black you will find for any beer of this style, and really for a stout I would consider this maximum dark. No light can penetrate. As one would expect from a beer with some age, there wasnt much of a head but with a hard pour I was able to get a decent one to show, with tan khaki bubbles and about 1/4 inch thickness. If the glass is moved at all, bubbles are generated and lace the glass with a dark brown color. Aroma is gorgeous with rich malt, blackberries,  blueberries, chocolate and roasted hops.Taste is amazing, showing a myriad of flavors, and really more appropriate for a sweet stout. Mouthfeel is medium thick, somewhat oily, and with perfect carbonation. Flavors include sweet berries, sweet/bitter chocolate, caramel, fruits (apple/pear). Aftertaste is warming alcohol, drying anise, wheat/oatmeal and blueberries. The dark fruits/berries are what really make me appreciative this beer. Very good, I cant even imagine how good it would be if it were a bit younger.

Courtesy of Mullman in trade. Pours murky dark brown with tiny sediment floaties, with no head. Aroma is chewy roasted malt, dark fruits and clove. Flavor is all over the place. Toffee, caramel, roasted grain, dark fruits, tiny bit of chocolate, and some yeasty bread. Great chewy, slightly oily palate. Looking at the glass it has residuel film coated everywhere. Alcohol is hidden better than any beer Ive had I believe. Very well done.

12oz - thanks ClarkVV - Aroma is chocolate and carmel malts with black licorice and clove.  Pours a solid black with no head and little lacing.  Flavor is bit bit musty (I might have waited too long to drink this one).  Sweet dark chocolate, carmel, clove, and roasty malts.  Palate is creamy and a little tart.  A tasty brew.

(12 oz bottle: Obtained in trade with MullMan, thanks Joe!) This is a winter wheat?  It pours as dark as a frickin porter!  But something bizarre has happened to this beer in just a few minutes.  Yeasties have now coagulated into hundreds of sizeable tan blobs, and they are suspended throughout the beer like a lab experiment in high school chemistry.  They are slowly settling to the bottom, but this is the craziest thing Ive ever seen with a beer.  Its cool to look at, but its also freaking me out a little.  It is so dense with this stuff that the carbonation bubbles are having a tough time weaving through the maze as they attempt to reach the surface.  It reminds me of a beer that is slightly frozen that its a slushee.  Anyway, the beer tastes and smells fine.  Well, actually, its better than fine, its great!  Sweet, loads of blackstrap molasses, strong dark malts and chocolate, dark fruits like prunes, very yeasty taste, kind of milky, and a fair amount of smoke on the back end.  Theres some wheat flavor here, but its kind of blotted out by the dark roasty malts.  As the beer warms, it tastes more and more like chocolate milk.  The nose is mostly roast, sweet chocolate and yeast.  Full bodied and dense, but not syrupy.  The mouthfeel is like someone added a thickening agent to my beer.  Dark brown color, obviously very cloudy and nearly opaque.  The small tan head didnt seem to last very long, but I was so enthralled the yeast blobs, I missed noting the head retention.  And interestingly enough, over time, all those yeast blobs have broken up, perhaps because the beer has warmed, or perhaps for some other reason, but with all that yeast "dissolved" into the liquid, it now has a milky appearance.  And the bottom of the bottle looks like Hersheys Syrup.  I gotta say, this is one of the most unique beer experiences of my rating career.  But I probably spent too much time on all the oddities, when I should have been enjoying the flavor, and make no mistake, this was a tasty brew, even it was a bit "darker" in flavor than authentic Weizen Bocks.

Beer #1 of the Ohio Labor Day gathering hosted by aofoxxy, brought by the one and only BBB63.  Sediment-rich dark brown body, reminiscent of prune juice, with a thin off-white head in an Orval glass.  Slightly tangy, toasty, wheaty aroma with a touch of prunes and plenty of layered breads.  Very bready flavor with hints of prune, toffee, and toast, light tanginess and a slight bitter biscuity character in the finish.  Complex and rich with evident alcohol notes.  Very good!

Bottle from jimmack. Pours a very flat black color. no head. aroma is wheat and roasty, malty. Taste is flat, then carbonated in the end. coats your mouth. Hints of chocolate, wheat, roast, but nothing really sticks out, kinda bland.

Caramel-brown body with a flat-fading, sudsy, dark tan head. Aroma of toasted raisins, clove spice, dark roast, and mild electrical fire phenolics. Flavor of caramel and Nutella with lots of malt character but nice dryness. Some light, noticeable oxidation and very low acidity. Would make a good cigar beer. Big thanks to SpringsLicker. I hunted for this fugitive beer for years.
Very little head which disipated quikly into very little lacing, oiley texture, lightly carbonated with carmel molasses taste.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: Very dark brown color with a thin light brown head. Aroma of smoked malt and molasses. Flavor of smoked malt and molasses with some sourness. Light to medium body with a dry texture and soft carbonation.

Thanks for this one Lou! Presents a small tan ring of a head that lasts. A black bodied brew with brown highlights. Roasty, chocolatey nose thats a touch rubbery with bananna notes, nice. Body is med/full, silky on the palate. Coffee flavors, roast, chocolate, black patent and a smidgen of cocoa with underlying ripe fruity notes. Solid malt backbone, very tastey. Dry, roasty finish. Lightly spicey. I,m a sucker for a Weizen Bock. Thanks again Lou18!

Thanks to richlikebeer or pailhead for this bonus brew.i cant remember wich box it came in.(sorry fellas)anway,here is my rating.pours a dark brown with a small creamy head that fades quickly.aromas of chocolate,wheat,and malts.much like a dunkel I would say.the flavor is much of the same with a little bit if sweet caramel thrown in.tis is pretty tasty and id drink it again if given the chance.

Thanks for the bottle, Duane. Brown and ruby colored body. Thin head that is slightly orange. The aroma has some rich notes of prunes and walnuts. There is also a little note caramel.
