The taste is sweet prunes and some spicy clove. There is also a little bit of caramel and a hint of English walnuts. A rather thin body for the very well hidden alcohol level. Nice.

Bottle.  Its the hottest and stickiest day of the year, and Im drinking a winter wheat.  Whatever.  Anyway, when I opened this, I was afraid it may have been infected.  There was no pop, no fizz and it poured with no head.  But, it did pour much darker than I had anticipated.  The aroma was light, some cloves, some grapes and pretty sweet.  At first sip, the flavor was pretty spicy (corriander and clove) and very vinous and astringent.  Grape and sweet malt presented itself as it warmed and the alcohol began to sit up.  It finishes dry and astringent.  My feeling is that the bottle wasnt infected, just oxidized.  Ill have to go back and rerate this one, probably in the winter months.  Thanks to jimmack04!

From a bottle,thanks richlikebeer, one of the last remaining starters.  An almost opaque dark brew.  Aroma of bitter chocolate and burnt wheat.  Flavor was interesting an almost nutty character with a flash of frutiness. A nice smooth finish, malty on the back end.  Overall, Id say its a keeper.

Opaque brown red with a small fizzy white head.  Subdued clove and fruit aromatics, with an undertone of allspice.  Caramel, molasses, and sharp dark wheat flavors.  Finish is almost grapey.  Very smooth and refreshing for 9.5%

Bottle - thanks to Eyedrinkale for the trade.  Pours dark brown, almost completely opaque with brick red highlights when held to light.  The smell is fascinating - sweet, rich, woody, molasses  malty aromas with bready yeasts, bananas, bubblegum and wildflowers.  The flavor is sweet and mellow, sugary black tea, herbs, hints of lemon and an alcohol tanginess.  Full body and little to no carbonation unless swished vigorously in the mouth.

foamy dark tan head that dashes away like a wood nymph.  mahogany-black color, with a dumping of brown yeast at the bottom of the glass.  bubbles come up the center of the surface like a hot spring in nevada.  aroma is smoky melted bananas, caramel malt too.  the mouthfeel is fizzy & creamy.  the flavor starts like blackstrap molasses, then shifts to a dry dark wheat maltyness.  no lacing on the glass.  a little smoky in the finish, a little dry.  clean aftertaste for a 9.5% beer.  but it sure is a unique weizen bock.  those crazy north jersey people!

sweet aroma typically found in weizens, but this one was mixed with chocolates, which i would have to say is a first for me.  color is a deep brown with some scarlet highlights...it looks almost like a porter, with about no head at all.  very sweet taste, with the banana and citrus effect of the wheat going rather nicely with the chocolates. a little bit of a tangyness, that i have to think comes from the abv.  body is very thick with a velvety/chewy mouthfeel, and the alcohol is again slightly evident in the aftertaste.  not like any weizen i have ever seen before, but quite enjoyable in its uniqueness.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2008 Once again, kudos for Richlikebeer for this bottle which was very fresh and up to date. My response to this beer is "interesting." I detected black currant and a raison-like taste (could be a combo fo flavors interacting there). It seems spicy but a bit malty for a wheat lover like myself. The mix kind of put my head in a twirl, not that the high alcohol content struck me.  It looks good and the mouthfeel is awesome. The aroma wasnt very evident to me after I drank it. Before I drank it, it made me wonder where my taste buds were travelling to. I may have to try this again to see if I can acquire its taste.
Rerate: I was on drugs when I gave this a 3.2! The mix of wheats and cloves and chocolate make this a nice malty liquid treat. Think Schneider Aventinus with some extra spices and chocolate malts. But still a bit soapy and soda pop feel.
ample thickness for a wheat beer,  nice dark black with a tannish head, nice wheat mixed with a roasted malt flavor, nice weizen, very solid
Dark opaque brown appearance, thin, quickly dissipating head formation. Banana clove aroma with slight smoked malt. Sweet brown sugar and black berry palate, a little smokey. Unique for sure.
Cloudy dark brown, disappearing light brown head. Cloying yeasty aroma with some sweet berry and toffee notes. Dry sweet flavor dominated by yeast. Rather sticky and scented and not my kind of beer.
pours a dark black with very little head.  Aroma is mainly yeast with a bit of malt.  Flavor is also mainly yeast with a bit of malt.

bottle thanks to lou.  rather unpleasant aroma (seems like everyone is rating this at 8/10....how and why??), comprised mostly of peanuts, banana, yeast, and a touch of malt.  much better-tasting than it smells, thankfully--caramel, marzipan & peanut brittle, some vinous hops show up as well.  im no fan of the style but despite my low-ish rating, this is very drinkable.  just hold your nose when you drink!
Replaces wine, with spiciness in yeast and dry finish. Multi-malts with chocolate malt and carmel. Thanks Clarkvv for the sample.

Thanks to ClarkVV for this brew.Dark brown with azero head but who cares when youopen the bottle and start to pour and this aroma creeps into your nose.This is like a big hearty bowl of chocolate malt-o-meal.The earthy wheat and all the luscious malts here are amazing.I hate to say this but it is almost like a Belgian Strong Ale with the amount of fruitiness.Has a real nice finish and the alcoholis barely present.Thanks again to ClarkVV.

Poured a very dark brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, raisins, spice, wheaty, and light alcohol.  Flavor is mostly chocolately, with dark fruit, a little of the wheaty citrus flavor.  Finishes with  spicey and dry.  Although it has a full mouthfeel it tastes light.  Hides the alcohol very well.

from the bottle, poured amber to brown, with a lght brown head, aroma, caramel, molasses, soy sauce, plums, dark chocolate colse to bitter sweet. flavor coffee where did that come from, smoke, wood, plums, do not taste the soy sauce. dry mouth feel. not to bad of a beer.

2004 bottle, second batch of the season, in an awesome trade with Maibockaddict.  Fabulous dark, caramel-brown color, muddy consistency, with plenty of sediment in the bottle.  Peppery carbonation at first, but allowing it to breath quickly solves that problem.  Tan head, lasting and lace-creating.  Aroma of clove cigarettes, banana, dark berries and light German hops.  Smells more like a hefe-weisse at first, but as it warms up and breathes more, some of the sweet caramel and raisin aroma is released.Flavor starts out with a rich toffee and caramel flavor, which is only lightly sweet.  Quickly transitions in to a more rounded wheat, sugar and chocolate mix with notes of ash and dry berry-skins as it finishes.  The more I drink, the more a distinct black currant flavor creeps in on my palate.  Towards the end of the bottle, I am marveling at how distinct, yet subtle it is.  Adds a light bitterness and slight astringency, which does not hurt the beer, but also adds a wondrous flavor.  I laughed when I read the commercial description, highly skeptical that there would be any real black currant flavor, but here it is.  Light clove and apple notes keep the sugars in check, while a faint dark chocolate adds great complexity.  Medium body and maybe a bit too much dryness  could be its only downfall, but I havent tried the other batch yet.  I cant detect the alcohol.
Bottled. Hazy dark brown. Banana aroma. Sweet and richly malty, full bodied. Some caramel and yeast as well as banana. Lightly grassy finish. A good weizenbock.
Very dark amber color; poor head. Quite classic Weizen Bock aroma, malty and caramel with a peculiar candies aroma. Quite sweet, oily, caramel, far from being complex

An unclear dark brown beer with a disappearing brown head. The aroma is sweet wheaty, but also with some berry notes. The flavor is sweet and dominated by wheat, but it also contains some berries. The end is quite dry and the mouthfeel very smooth.

Bottled: Dark amber coloured. Murky. Brown dense head. Berries, sweetness and alcohol in the aroma. Flavour of yeast, spices, fruit, wheat and malt. Light fruity and light bitter end. Mighty nice brew. Thanks Springslicker for trading this.

Bottle.  Deep black color.  Small tannish head is slow to form and fast to fade.  No lacing.  Aroma is heavily of coffee.  Medium to full bodied.  Slick mouthfeel.  Some carbonation.  Alcohol hidden well.  Really a nice Weizenbock.  Thanks Lou!!!

courtesy of lmgraz1.  Bottle, best if before August, but no year.  Dark brown pour, hazy, no head.  Heavier aroma than the Classic Wheat.  Smoke, dark chocolate, roasted malt aromas.  Dark pit fruit flavors to start, nice roasted malt in the middle with chocolate and smoke.  Nice mild bitterness and a very mild warming sensation to finish.  This is a wonderfully crafted selection.  Very complex and absolutely enjoyable.  Thanks Lou for this gem!

Vintage 1999. Ratebeer rating # 800. Poured a dark black with a light reddish tint at the edges with a large tan head. Aromas and tasets of soy, chocolate, wheat, and light bananas. Smoke in the aroma as well. Alcohol content hidden. This one aged well.

Tap at Andys.  I have no idea what everyone else thinks they are drinking, but this was a beautiful, creamy, delicious beer.  The ample tan (almost greyish) head just looked so enticing.  Like the color of a chocolate milkshake.  The actual beer color was very dark brown or red.  This was so creamy.  Delicious malt tastes.  Wow.  Either Im rating the wrong beer or everyone else is telling lies

Toffee taste.  Really really delicious, a couple layers above Sam Adams Winter Lager for winter beer quality.  A new favorite, fresh from the brewery at Andys.  Really good stuff, tasty and complex, and just enough heft.
dark reddish brown with no head. Low on carbonation..Aroma smokey.  Flavor is smokey, malty, with some vinegar/soy sauce...i enjoyed this beer but dont think i like it very much..know what i mean?

Dark mohogany color with very little head. Typical wheat beer aroma of cloves and banana, but with a nice hint of chocolate malts. Flavor was mildly sweet chocolate malts, clove and smoke. Very smooth texture and finish.
I can see me drinking these all winter long.

Dark amber in color. Not much head, 
high in alcohol taste. Smell of spices and chocolate with a warming feeling.

Deep, dark red with a thin, tan head.  The aroma is meaty and thick with tons of chocolate, banana, clove, tart wheat, alcohol, pencil shavings, whole grains and a light touch of bubblegum.  Thick and round, the body is satisfying, though somewhat lacking in carbonation.  The flavor is good, but seems a bit old.  The malt is definitely dominate, though the flavors seem muted.  The chocolate and banana rule while the spicy yeast seems to take a backseat.  Its not bad, but I would like a fresher sample to see how it would make things different.  Thanks Santa!

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2004 bottle obtained in my first trade.  pours a cloudy, dark cola color with a reddish edge.  nicely balanced without a lot of carbonation.  As good as advertised!  Thanks to lmgraz1 for the great trade.  you da man, Lou

2001 bottle. Pours cloudy brown with a light brown head. Wow! great aroma of various dark fruit with an alcohol buzz. Taste has notes of brown sugar, molasses, wood, dark fruit and spices. Very smooth on the palate with little if no carbonation. Overall, really good stuff.

2001 Bottle sampled 12/4/04: Dark, hazy brown, has tons of sediment and yeast visable, with a tan head.  Aroma: chocolate, wheat, molasses, spice, lots of malt, banana, plum.  Flavor: molasses, brown sugar, pepper, yeast, apple, and pear.  Nice.

Rich, sweet, spicy aroma, some brown sugar, roastiness and clove along with notes of banana, red grape, plum, licorice, cocoa and faint, peppery alcohol.  Opaque dark brown in color with a creamy, fine, tan head.  Flavor is largely sweet and fruity, balanced very nicely by the spiciness of the yeast and subtle hop flavors towards the gently warming finish.  Pleasant interplay of characteristics.  Smooth and lightly creamy mouthfeel, decidedly full body.  Complex and satisfying.   I had been wanting to try this one for quite some time.  Thanks a lot, Jay!
WOW!  This is a strong wheat beer...and a great one at that.  Very easy to drink and full of flavor...recommended.

Mmm. Had the first of this years batch at High Points monthly brewery tour. Pours black with a small head. I have never smelled a better aroma come off of a beer. Wow! Malty, wheaty, and not too carbonated like Aventinus.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2005 Dark, beautiful. Nice brown head. Balanced malt, aroma of chocolate and ... awesome. This is a great beer. Get this if you can. I must say It loses a few points when not on tap, but still a wonderful beer for those who like it dark.

Dark brown, no head. Aroma of plums and smoke. Richly bitter with a nice very smoky flavor, with hints of prune. Not nearly as sweet as it smells. As it warms, hint of tobacco and whisky emerge. Very tasty. Thanks to Springslicker for this one!

Fully dark in color, not a bit of light escaping, with a fine, cocoa-tan head. So far, this looks like no wheat of any sort or stripe Ive ever met.
Aroma: big, overpowering fruit, grapes, cherries, bright and lively, with a slightly smokey, woodsy edge.
Good texture, delicious taste, body on the medium side.
Truly a joy to drink, this one, with a marvelous, lovely flavor, nice, medium finish, smooth, supreme drinkability, if lacking in overall complexity.
Additionally, I had no suspicion of its high ABV, 9.5%!, until entering these notes. Perhaps the strength lulled me into missing its presence?

By far and away the darkest weiss Ive ever had. Dark brown with a smaller head that settles to a small lid of tan bubbles. Earthy molasses aromas along with a hearty fruit cake backdrop. At is all about the flavor in this one. Sweet wheat start with nuances of fruit and mild spice. Thick and chewy feel.  Very smooth and drinkable for the heft. Mild dark chocolate in the finish that makes this one feel like dessert.  Thanks to CaptainCougar for helping me have this long on my list brew.

This was a Springslicker special, thanks Jay! This beer poured a brown color with ruby red hints running throughout. It came with a slighty tanned head which dissipated rapidly. The aroma is woody, and peppery with ginger and vanilla notes, hints of banana, citrus, clove and fig leaves. Theres also this perfect smell of mahogany wood as well...its interesting to say the least. The alcohol is warming with peppers, vanilla, and ginger doing most of the work. Theres a sweet finish, dry but not as much as i expected. Theres a good helping of malt near the finish as well. Nicely balanced for a winter beer.

Mahogany black with a faded khaki head thats airy and fleeting. Licorice in the aroma with a slight bubblegum ester note backing it up. Theres a lot of complexity in the flavor with chocolate, an interesting cross of tea and coffee, charcoal and more of those bubblegum esters.

Dark brown color with smallish head. Nice roasted aromas of wheat and light bittersweet chocolate. Taste was malty with light ripe cherries with a smooth finish. Medium bodied and not too sweet. Quite good.

Almost an opaque brown color with a average Bock head. Aroma of chocolate and heavy caramel. Rich flavor of malt, raisin, and caramel fudge. Smooth finish.
Tasty brew!

Gorgeous purple-brown, dark, firm lasting head.  Smells pumpernickel, prunes, alcohol, yeast, banana, spice, gorgeous!  Taste: big bold wheat, raisin, peaches, mulled wine, in the middle seems to thicken on the tongue.  Coating, warming finish.  Got some coffee tones when it warmed up a bit.  Not as creamy as Aventinus but really good!
Brewtopia 2004:  Dark brown with a thin off-white head.  Chocolate aroma, with bits of dark fruits.  Smooth bodied, good sweet ending.  Long rich aftertaste.

Chocolate, pumpernickel malt (H); plums, prunes, raisins, brown sugar aroma.  Deeeeep ruby body, almost black.  Heavily sweet, lightly acidic flavor becomes a moderately sweet finish.  Madeira in the finish.  Medium-full body, oily texture, lively carbonation.  The bottom line is: excellent!  If only the body was creamier!

Dark beer with ruby hints when held up to the light.  Brown head that quickly dissappeared.  Brown sugar and molasses nose.  Very malty beer.  Lots of dried fruit, bread, subtle spice and alcohol as it warms.  Bitter chocolate finish.  Very nice beer.  Thanks to BBB63 for the bottle.
Brewtopia 04 Word for word in my notepad " i hate wheat beer ehh not for me

Brewtopia04.  Big and malty nose; alcohol front.  Bubblegummy.  Banana yeastiness.  Rivals many German doppels.  I was too busy chatting with Dave (MaiBockAddict) to write a wordy description, but I did jot these legit numbers.  Excellent beer.

Dark brown body with a some what lasting tan head.  Malty aroma has some bannanna/clove things happening with a bit of alcohol and some yeasty notes.  Flavor starts sweet and malty with some wheat and musty earth notes, maybe a bit of fruitiness in there, this fades into a light roasted malt coffee finish. Has a bit of bitter twoards the end but the palate seems some what bland and flat. Not bad.

Aroma is sweet and fruity (berries, plums, raisins) with roasted malts, chocolate and coffee notes. Dark brown, opaque with large bubbled, tan head that recedes to ring. Dark fruits dominate this malty sweet beer with a rasty finish. Flavour is a bit short. Smooth, creamy mouthfeel and medium body. Enjoyed with MartinT and Rastacouere. Bottle.

Very deep chestnut brown body with almost no head, only a light brown ring. Aroma lets anticipate a rather thick beer and holds all kinds of malt subtleties, smoky licorice, chocolate, hints of coffee and wheat and just any dark fruit you can name or not. Very fruity palate. The malt profile is actually quite sweet, feeling like brown sugar at times, but the supervising smokiness comes in handy to ensure this never gets cloying. The fruit character is just splendid, chewy plums and fresh black berries. This is a garden Id like to possess. Carbonation is rather low to style, but I enjoy it that way and the medium body just carries the flavor like a pro. Spectacular and stunning every way I look at it, absolutely blinding me of any potential critics.
Small dark head, very dark appearance. A little burnt malt with light hops. It had a heavy and a little sweet yeasty taste to it. The finish is semi-sweet and short.

Almost black with a small, tan head. Cellarlike, yeasty aroma, maybe a bit smoky.

I found the flavour somehow undistinguished, but I like the palate, which is somehow very right for the beer IMO.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2004 a bit of a let down. A regular dunkel, spicy aroma, a little hoppy with a wee bit of burned malt, extremely well balanced is it´s best side, nice beer overall but I was expecting something more

Poured a dark licorce/ raspberry color with an aroma of licorce and currant.  There was a lsight warmth in the taste almost like a brandy with some chocolate and caramel undertones at the end. The aftertaste was again warm with a bit of brandy and somewhat sweet.

Draft at TAP NY.  Cloudy deep mahogany with an off-white heaed.  Slight malty nose.  Roasted sweet malty sour taste with maybe a hint of some yeasts in there.  Slightly overcarbonated, with some wateryness.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2008 A good  beer.  Much better than I remember it the first time I had it.  As Im not typically a fan of wheat beers, but this is well-balanced.  Wheaty and malty, with just a hint of bitterness. The strong maltiness pairs well with the caramel notes.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2008 [year after year, this beer reveals more of its wonders to me - subtle, smooth, creamy - perfectly balanced - the only reason this isnt rated over a 4 is because its not blunt enough, IMHO] [draught] Very dark, nearly stout-like appearance - caramel and clove in the aroma - flavor has a tartness to it that takes a lot of getting used to, but once the palate adjusts, the warm flavors and caramel, chocolate, dark fruits and a touch of currant greet you - not as balanced as I expected, but good.

Bottle pours a dark chocolate color a minor tannish head.   Aroma is very much like a German Wheat, with notes of fruit.   Definately smells inviting!   Up front this one is very wheaty, followed by a smooth malty finish.   Faint tastes of chocolate and fruit as well.   Medium body, lasting finish, this is a fantastic Winter offering!   Slight warming feeling now makes its presence.   Thanks goes out to TChrome for the trade!

Bottle.  Smelled like a Belgian beer, tasted like a Belgian beer, finished like a Belgian beer.  If I wanted a Belgian beer (which I don't) I would buy a Belgian beer!  Loaded with that yeasty, horrible banana taste that all Belgian beers possess.  The bottle said this was a German style beer.  They are wrong it is a Belgian style beer.  If you haven't guessed by now, I HATE Belgian beers.  I will not buy this beer again!

12 oz bottle.  Thick, viscous nearly black, with creamy medium head that folds into a lasting wisp of white.  Wonderfully deep aromas of banana creme, chocolate, Dr. Pepper, soft herbs.  Very sweet with more than a hint of underlying sharp sour fruits, incredible thick milk-shake body saved from syrupiness by everpresent light carbonation, chocolate-cherry-cola finish.  A masterpiece.

A really interesting off blackish color with some purpley hints around the edges, nice dark tan head about a pinky high of thick, lush foam, sits a bit before diminshing to a thick collar, no real lace sticking, a few miniscule spots. Aroma is muted sweet malts with a nice deepness of raisin, some dark cherry, vanilla, and softly rounded alcohol warmth;also, a bit funky with some smokeyness. A nice nose as it warms. Taste is favorably malty sweet with a little touch of tartness from some dark cherry aspects, which mixes with some raisin and sweetish wheat tones that surface after midway and lingers into the finish with a bit more fullness then at the start. Notes of vanilla and molasses in there. Feel starts slow but builds from there quite nicely gaining some and ending full and sweet with a floating easy finish. Smooth and lightly creamy overall. A nice drinkable Weissbock.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2004 Pretty compelling aroma of wheat and roasted malt.  Beer pours very dark brown with tan head that almost completely dissipates.  Flavor is fruity, malty, with a little roastiness.  Seems a bit thin on the palate relative to my expectation.  Very good winter beer.
Excellent head when given a stiff pour.  Incredible banana-clove esters.  Full creamy mouthfeel leaves with a smooth caramel/malty taste.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2005 Wow, much darker than expected, little head though. The aroma hinted of banana, citrus, spice, toasted malt, mocha, coffee, and light caramel. Nice and floral. Weizen character upfront (banana, citrus, and spice) followed with a taste more towards the bock style (malt, buttered toast, and caramel). The finish had a nice spicy and coffee component. The mouthfeel was creamy and lush. One of the best of the genre, a must try for any Ratebeerian.

Beautious weizenbock, eh?  Dark, deep red.  Great nose, massive banana esters.  Big malts in this one, nicely fruity.  Spicy, good fruits, good lemon/banana character, also a bit smoky with some tobacco.  Simply blooms in the mouth, flavor explodes across the entire tongue.

This beer greeted me with candy and floral scents and a beautiful, thick, dark brown color.  To me it tasted of bananas and licorice.  The carbonation was light, and the aftertaste slightly bitter.  This beer is probably better than the rating I'm giving it, but it just doesn't do it for me.

On the pour a deep brown to black with some ruby high lights and the head modest in size, creamy in texture and the color a dark tan with the lace a thick and glutinous sheet to seal off the glass for view. Ah that smell, sweet wheat, cloves, and a hint of licorice, also some toasted tones noticed, quite a sniffer this one, start is sweet and thick, the top middling in feel. Finish is benignly acidic and the hops mild and pleasant in their spiciness with the aftertaste bone dry and a fine beer that I've wanted to try for quite a while.

I was surprise how black this was and how small of a head it was able to produce.  Certain imperial stout characteristics inform this weizenbock, some are welcome, others choke out the more delicate fruity flavors.  I've wanted to try this one for so long, and I admit being a bit let down.  It was, however, nice to taste something other than an Aventinus clone.

Clear dark brown-ruby with anice light brown head. Big wheat aroma, esthers, banana, and clove. The flavor is outstanding, vanilla, banana and clove that blooms throughtout the taste. Big smooth body. This is a really nice weizen bock.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2006 Poured a dark brown, with reddish hue, and a tan, quickly diminishing head.  Aroma of wheat, yeast, bananas-n-cream, and clove spice.  Nice spicy weizenbock (banana and clove) taste, with a mild alcohol tingle on the tongue.
Black cola with minimal head.  Aroma is sweet, licorice, clove, banana, alcohol.  Taste is sweet, wheat, finishing clove and light banana.  Medium-full body.

Ruby red hue with small tan head.  Wheat and clove aroma noticeable.  Yeasty hefe aroma.   Flavor is a little bit of a letdown after the aroma but it is still very good.  Strong flavor with no alcohol burn.  Great beer.
This is a great Weizen Bock.  Fruity, malty, and earthy flavors.  Finishes clean, smooth, and creamy.
(Draught) Thin, brown head and an opaque body. Thick caramel malt with vanilla tones. Excellent example of a weizen bock. Beautiful!
Dark lager with a spicy malty nose. Choclate notes in the mouth, with some of the spices and malt complementing each other. very nice beer...thanks to MBA

Murky, brown lager with a small, fizzy, well-tanned head. Decent retention. No lacing.
Good, hearty aroma. Raisins, chocolate,  yeast, dark bread and bubblegum.
The flavor is well-balanced and slightly astringent. Medium-bodied with a watery mouthfeel and mellow carbonation. Lengthy, astringent, lightly bitter finish.
Overrated!

This brew pours with a dark brown, almost black body topped by a medium thick head and a decent amount of lacing left on the glass.  The malty aroma is sweet and candy like with some yeasty notes.  The flavor is sweet and malty with a candy note, very slight yeasty notes and a touch of alcohol.  Medium to full bodied, slightly dry and warming.
dark brown with a halo of sudz..smokey peat, malty and cola-ish aromas...smokey/malty flavors with burnt grass and bitter chocolate notes..

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2004  Want to update my comments: The 8.25% was a fluke. Second batch is bigger and richer, with an abv more around 9.3%. There is a third batch coming out soon that will also reflect a bigger beer. . This years version is 8.25% ABV. Much more like an Aventinus, only darker, richer, and a tad sweeter. Pours very dark, with a tan head. Nice and sweet wheat beer aroma (clove and banana), with hints of the dark malt. Full palate, with sweet malt flavor, and the clove notes from the yeast. Well made and a change from the usual Russian Imperial likeness from last year.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text:
UPDATED: MAY 4, 2008 2005 Winter Wheat,drank today. Wow. It held up really well..  Deep dark brown in color with a nice fluffy off white head. Its still tasting very smooth. Very drinkable.

2007 Had this yesterday fresh from the brewery. Took some home in a growler. Very good. Really enjoyed this. Well balanced with malt and hops. I tasted chocolate and there was some caramel notes too. Very smooth. Subtle alcohol. Dark in color. Good winter beer, really warms you up. 

I just had this from a new batch. Second batch is more malty. Very good beer. More alcohol too. Well balanced.

Dark as slightly used motor oil with an ephemeral khaki head. Syrupy smell of chocolate, cherries, molasses, and toasted malt.  Only a hint of wheat twang in the aroma - maybe being overwhelmed by the roasted malts. Semi-sweet with a slightly sour finish underneath a load of toast and burnt notes. I like this brew, wish it was distributed here.

2002? bottle. Head is initially small, frothy, brown, fully diminishing. Body is black (almost opaque), bottle conditioned. Aroma is lightly malty (caramel, toasted dark bread), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with light notes of banana, clove, and dark brown sugar, hint of raisin. Flavor is heavily sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Medium to full body, watery/syrupy texture, lively carbonation. I think this is the '02 version, but the brewer doesn't mark the bottling year unfortunately.  The aroma is perhaps a little TOO subtle, but what is there is pleasant. The flavor profile is too syrupy sweet, but definitely rich. Overall I wouldn't call this world class. It's certainly no Aventinus.  But it's still quite good.

Aroma is of a smoked beer completely with less wheaty clove/banana profile than I expected.  As the cougar say really a smoked weizen bock.  At first I thought the typical weizenbock characteristics to be completely hidden, but they emerge from behind the smoke to create a beer unlike any other I have tried.  Great.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2003 Delicious dark as hell brew.  Beautiful bottle and glass.  Wonderful dark stout like taste, unlike a lot of weizen brews.  not as good as Aventinus, but pretty good. It really does look like flat cola when i poured it, and it had little head.
Super dark brown/black.  Very smokey aroma, malty.  More light-bodied than the aroma/appearance would suggest.  A good bite with regard to alcohol and spice.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2007 Rerate 5/27/05: Pour yields very little head and about the same color as before.  The main difference I notice between the different batches is that this one seems dryer and more roasty without that great smoky caramel sweetness I remember from before.
Still hides its alcohol well, but isnt quite as to style as the past version.  Many thanks to richlikebeer for the chance to try this again. 
Original rating 7/23/03: Pours a rich dark brown with a thin tan head and sweet caramel smokey malt aroma. Tremendously thick sweet and smokey body has good complexity of dark malts.  Nice malty wheat flavor as well.  This is a great beer, like a smoked weizenbock.

This weizen bock pours a deep black color with a thin, tan head that dissipates rapidly. The aroma is very complex with hints of bubblegum, dark fruits, wheat, and malts. It has a medium to full body with a smooth, creamy mouthfeel and low carbonation. The flavor is richly sweet and malty with hints of caramel, yeast, and banana. It hides its 9.5 ABV very well. A nice weizen bock, though not quite as spectacular as Aventinus.

Looks like a porter, but doesn't taste like one! Slightly fruity aroma w/ a flavor of tart cherries & brown bread. Velvety on the tongue w/ a slightly sweet finish. This is a great brew. Thx herbjones
Looks like dark bock.  Chocolate color, tan rim of head around the glass.  Fruity wheat aroma.  Flavor of bread, banana, and clove.  Soft mouthfeel with a carmel like finish.  Excellent brew!

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2006 (Brochure sent by my friend mittenstein): "Our itinerary then takes us to the walls of Truffle where Toffee was born and the Berries (the Blue, the Field and the rebel Cherry) took refuge long ago...This is where you will visit the famed Date mural (pronounced da-tay of course), which dissimulates still today a dark, syrupy story of Olympian tobacco proportions...In the hindmost chamber, you will also discover how astonishingly close Weizenbocks can be to Imperial Stouts...This is where sacrificial offerings of lamb were made, always slathered by plums, raisins, molasses and decadent festivities...Dont worry, on this world tour of flavors, there will be many occasions for pictures...

Compared to Aventinus, the Weizenbock style standard imho, this one is somewhat less effervescent, leans towards the bock more than the weizen, and thus possesses a fuller malt body and richer malt profile. I might prefer Aventinus for its heavily estery personality, and Belgian-like vivacity, but Ramsteins would be a better late-evening sipper than Aventinus. Both excellent beers, any way you like at them.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2003 Hats off to Ramstein for hiding almost 10% abv without a trace.  Remarkable!  Dark and coffeeish in the glass, though not with a head like in the attached picture.  Ramstein certainly knows how to brew a wheat beer, and this hold up against the best weizen bocks.  However, I think I'll take Mac Frost Winter Ale over this by a nose.  Granted, the Ramstein has tremendous malt and syrupy complexity, but it just isn't quite my thing.  The clove-ish taste gets to me after awhile.

You have to hold this one to the light to realize this is a deep,deep dark chestnut brown. Hints of clove,nutmeg and black licorice meld with a big back bone of roasted malt. Definately has a wheaty tartness resembling Granny Smith apples. Nice full body but very light on the tongue lending to a ridiculous drinkability at 9.5% I could drink this one on a daily basis if it were only available in California.

Large, sticky, smooth tan head.  Deep ruddy brown colour.  Nose of bananas, plums, cloves, apple.  Oh my...Very viscous, yet light footed because of lively carbonation.  Coats the mouth with layers of different flavors.  Chocolate, plum, raison, dark bread, banana.  Lightly acidic bite on the lingering finish.  Alcohol is hidden oh so well.  Im terribly impressed with this brew.  Who knew that Jersey water could be transformed into such a great winter brew!  How can anyone rate this above Aventinus?!

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2003 Extremely,dark,brown,beer with a creamy,clingy,tan head. Subtle,brandyish aromas of dark bread,yeast-fruitiness,black currant,chocolate and a little alcohol.Mouthfeel is lusciously,thick with carbonation that allows flavors to gently slide over the tounge.Sweet,tropical,bready flavors please the palate.Perfectly flavorful.Very soft,smooth lightly sweet,earthy hop finish. This is a hugely rich and satisfying beer but at the same time has typical Weizen bock qualities.Top notch!

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2006 Plum in color.  Imperial stout-like light bronze foam.  Round aroma of chocolate coated passion fruit, plump raisin, cream, jellied cassis, concord grape, tar, very vague citric hop and chocolate undertones, leather, licorice, plantain, prune, and hop leaf.  Slick, slightly oily palate.  Firm carbonation.  Faint oxidation.  Tantalizing of complexity here.  Starts with chocolate clove notes, before moving to licorice, mild charcoal, rich bready textures, and dessert apples.  Rich burnt coffee finish matched with lovely oozings of caramel, mint chocolate, and rich toffee.  Seriously displays Imperial Stout complexity and burnt chocolate with Weizenbock yeast and clove flavors.  With less oxidation and a fuller body, this would be perfect.  Absolutely amazing.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Very dark brown (cola-esque) colour; pours kind of syrupy w/o much foam.  Aroma of banana, plum, dark malt, industrial cheddar; oily, viscous body; on the palate dark fruits overlay smooth, sweet malts (like what an all-malt Peruvian black beer would taste like) with fruits (peach, plum, banana).  More dark malt than usual for the style but it isn't roasty at all.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2003 Massive malts must warm before this beast releases all of it's flavor.  Sweet and thick, bready at times. The high alcohol is well masked, but gives it complexity.  Superb caramel and toffee flavors rule. Thanks to Venom for this nice beer that I drank during the Superbowl.
High Point does it again with a fantastic wheat.  This beer has wonderful caramel flavors and a wonderful mouthfeel
Wow, this makes me wish it was always winter.  Thick and rich with layers of flavor.  Great on a cold winter night.
Strong, hearty brew with authority 7&lots of flavor! Great brew! Nothing bad here at all!
Too strong if anything is wrong.
